Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n A complete Bell\u2010state analyzer for two frequency\u2010bin qubits (abstract 2-dimensional systems) using ancilla photons and linear optics. Physically one implements the tunable beamsplitters via plasmonic nanocavities to mix spectral modes, but Pytheus treats everything abstractly.\n\nExplanation:\n We label the two input qubits as in_nodes = [0,1], each carrying one photon in an unknown Bell state (|\u03a6\u00b1> or |\u03a8\u00b1>). We introduce two ancillary single-photon sources (single_emitters = [2,3]) whose photons feed into the same linear-optical network. The optimized network then routes the four photons into four distinct detectors. We assign four unique click-patterns (each a 2-photon coincidence among the four detectors) to the four Bell states, achieving unambiguous discrimination.\n\nVisualization (photons move top\u2192bottom):\n emitters:       [2]       [3]\n inputs:         [0]       [1]\n network:        [  to be optimized  ]\n detectors:      [A] [B] [C] [D]\n\nTarget mapping (target_quantum):\n  \u2013 Detection pattern P\u2081 = {1,1,0,0} \u21d2 |\u03a6+>\n  \u2013 P\u2082 = {1,0,1,0} \u21d2 |\u03a6\u2013>\n  \u2013 P\u2083 = {0,1,0,1} \u21d2 |\u03a8+>\n  \u2013 P\u2084 = {0,0,1,1} \u21d2 |\u03a8\u2013>\n\nConfig skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Frequency\u2010bin Bell\u2010state analyzer with plasmonic\u2010nanocavity tunable beamsplitters\",\n  foldername: \"freqBin_BSM\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  single_emitters: [2,3],\n  in_nodes: [0,1],\n  target_quantum: [\"1100\",\"1010\",\"0101\",\"0011\"],\n  removed_connections: [],    # allow all mixing\n  number_resolving: True,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  loss_func: \"heralded_bsm\",  # custom loss that rewards one\u2010to\u2010one mapping of patterns to Bell labels\n  edges_tried: 40,\n  samples: 20\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting:\n\u2013 A full Bell\u2010state analyzer for frequency bins overcomes the 50% limit of passive linear optics alone.  \n\u2013 Tunable plasmonic nanocavities give practical spectral selectivity; abstract network design by Pytheus provides the blueprint.  \n\u2013 Such an analyzer is a key building block for high-rate, spectrally multiplexed quantum networks and teleportation protocols.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed target\u2014a four-click, ancilla-assisted linear-optical network that unambiguously discriminates all four Bell states of two frequency-bin qubits\u2014is essentially the well-known ancilla-assisted complete Bell\u2010state analyzer first discussed for polarization qubits (e.g. Grice, Phys. Rev. A 84, 042331 (2011) and related schemes using two extra photons). Simply porting this idea from polarization to frequency bins, even with plasmonic nanocavities as frequency-mode beam splitters, does not introduce a genuinely new quantum\u2010optical primitive or fundamental effect beyond mode-conversion details. Because complete, heralded Bell\u2010state analyzers using two single\u2010photon ancillas and number-resolving detection are already established in the literature, this proposal lacks the novelty required for a PRL target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The ancilla-assisted 100%-efficient Bell\u2010state measurement using two extra photons in a static linear-optical network (Grice 2011 and follow-ups) already covers this functionality\u2014merely translating it to frequency bins with tunable plasmonic beamsplitters is an implementation detail rather than a new conceptual advance. To be considered, you would need to identify a fundamentally different mechanism (e.g. bypassing the two-ancilla requirement, using a new quantum interference effect, or demonstrating an unforeseen information-processing capability) rather than adapting a known scheme to a new degree of freedom.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n  \u201cSpectral\u2010Mode Entanglement Swap Router\u201d  \nWe prepare two independent Bell\u2010pairs in two spectral channels, f1 and f2, shared between Alice and Bob on one side and Bob and Charlie on the other:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2081 (f1): A\u2081\u2013B\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2082 (f2): A\u2082\u2013B\u2082  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2083 (f1): C\u2081\u2013D\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2084 (f2): C\u2082\u2013D\u2082  \nAt Bob\u2019s station we input modes B\u2081, B\u2082, C\u2081, C\u2082 into a single static linear-optical network (to be optimized by Pytheus), together with four ancillary photons (from pair sources or single emitters). By engineering ancilla coupling to be spectral\u2010selective (abstractly via removed_connections), different ancilla\u2010click patterns herald three distinct entanglement\u2010swapping operations:\n\n  1. One-hop swap in f\u2081 (ancillas 1&2 click) \u2192 entangle A\u2013C.  \n  2. One-hop swap in f\u2082 (ancillas 3&4 click) \u2192 entangle C\u2013F.  \n  3. Two-hop swap across f\u2081\u2192f\u2082 (all four ancillas click) \u2192 entangle A\u2013F.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n pair\u2010sources:   [pair_f1]  [pair_f2]  [pair_f1]\n                A\u21920      C\u21922      E\u21924\n                B\u21921      D\u21923      F\u21925\n\n ancilla sources:         [6]  [7]  [8]  [9]\n\n inputs to network:       [1][2][3][4]  (B,C,D,E)\n\n network:                 [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]\n\n detectors:               [d0][d1][d2][d3]  (monitor 1\u20134)\n\n ancilla detectors:       [d4][d5][d6][d7]  (monitor 6\u20139)\n\nConfig skeleton for Pytheus:\n{\n  description: \"Spectral-Multiplexed Hierarchical Entanglement Switch\",\n  foldername: \"spec_multihop_swap\",\n  in_nodes: [1,2,3,4],            # B,C,D,E\n  num_anc: 4,                     # ancilla photons at modes 6\u20139\n  single_emitters: [],            # using probabilistic pair sources\n  removed_connections: [\n    # ancillas 6,7 only connect to B(1) & C(2): f\u2081\u2010swap\n    [6,3],[6,4],[7,3],[7,4],\n    # ancillas 8,9 only connect to D(3) & E(4): f\u2082\u2010swap\n    [8,1],[8,2],[9,1],[9,2]\n  ],\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"1100----\", result: \"swap f1 (A\u2013C)\"},\n    {pattern: \"0011----\", result: \"swap f2 (C\u2013F)\"},\n    {pattern: \"1111----\", result: \"two-hop swap (A\u2013F)\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func: \"heralded_multi_swap\",  # custom loss rewarding correct multi-outcome swaps\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  samples: 20,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy this is exciting:\n  \u2022 First demonstration of a \u201cquantum repeater switch\u201d that conditionally performs different numbers of entanglement\u2010swap hops and selectively operates in two spectral channels\u2014all in one static, ancilla-assisted network.  \n  \u2022 Abstractly captures the concept of spectral tunability via plasmonic\u2010cavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters without dynamic control.  \n  \u2022 Lays the groundwork for hierarchical, multiplexed quantum\u2010network routing\u2014immediately extensible to more channels or more hops.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The \u201cSpectral-Multiplexed Hierarchical Entanglement Switch\u201d is essentially a straightforward extension of existing ancilla-heralded entanglement-swap router/switch schemes\u2014simply adding a third click pattern to choose between two single-hop swaps or a two-hop swap across frequency channels. All the core ideas (static linear optics, ancilla-driven multi-outcome swapping, spectral mode selection via removed_connections) closely mirror prior spectral routers and multi-outcome Bell-swap primitives in the ensemble. There is no new interference principle (e.g. indefinite causal order), no resource saving (ancilla count grows with outcomes), nor a qualitatively new network capability beyond trivial multi-pattern relabeling.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This proposal does not offer a fundamentally new photonic primitive beyond existing ancilla-assisted spectral entanglement routers or multi-outcome swap schemes. To reach PRL level novelty, you would need to identify an unprecedented interference effect (e.g. coherent superposition of swap orders), remove the ancilla-overhead scaling with outcome count, or demonstrate a routing primitive that cannot be reduced to sequential Bell swaps with different heralding patterns.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n  \u201cSpectral-Multiplexed Hierarchical Entanglement Switch\u201d\n\nWe prepare three Bell-pairs in two spectral channels:\n  \u2022 Pair\u2081 (f\u2081): A\u2013B  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2082 (f\u2082): C\u2013D  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2083 (f\u2081): E\u2013F  \n\nPhotons B,C,D,E enter a single static linear-optical network together with four ancilla photons (from pair-sources or single emitters). By engineering spectral-selective ancilla routing (via removed_connections), different ancilla-click patterns herald three distinct swapping operations:\n\n  1. One-hop swap in f\u2081: ancillas 1&2 click \u2192 entangle A\u2013C  \n  2. One-hop swap in f\u2082: ancillas 3&4 click \u2192 entangle C\u2013F  \n  3. Two-hop cross-channel swap: all four ancillas click \u2192 entangle A\u2013F  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n pair-sources:   [pair_f1]  [pair_f2]  [pair_f1]  \n                A\u21920      C\u21922      E\u21924  \n                B\u21921      D\u21923      F\u21925  \n\n ancilla sources:         [6]  [7]  [8]  [9]  \n\n inputs to network:       [1][2][3][4]  (B,C,D,E)  \n\n network:                 [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]  \n\n detectors:               [d0][d1][d2][d3]  (monitor 1\u20134)  \n ancilla detectors:       [d4][d5][d6][d7]  (monitor 6\u20139)  \n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Spectral-Multiplexed Hierarchical Entanglement Switch\",\n  foldername: \"spec_multihop_swap\",\n  in_nodes: [1,2,3,4],            # custom loss rewarding correct multi-outcome swaps\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  samples: 20,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n \u2013 First \u201cquantum repeater switch\u201d that conditionally performs different numbers of entanglement-swap hops and selectively operates in multiple spectral channels\u2014in one static device.  \n \u2013 Captures the spirit of spectral tunability (plasmonic-nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters) in an abstract, feedback-free linear-optical network.  \n \u2013 Opens a new route to hierarchical, spectrally-multiplexed quantum-network primitives and can be generalized to more channels or hops.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The \u201cSpectral-Multiplexed Hierarchical Entanglement Switch\u201d is just a straightforward extension of the same ancilla-heralded, static linear-optical entanglement-swap router/switch concept you\u2019ve already proposed (and which closely parallels ensemble ideas like the \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router\u201d and the \u201cMultiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\u201d). Merely adding a third click pattern for a two-hop swap in another frequency channel does not introduce a new interference mechanism, resource efficiency, or fundamental network capability beyond trivial multi-outcome relabeling. This fails to meet the bar for a genuinely novel PRL-worthy quantum-optical primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To reach novelty, you\u2019d need to propose a qualitatively new routing primitive\u2014such as a coherent superposition of multiple swap orders, ancilla-free multi-outcome routing, or a nonclassical interference effect that cannot be reduced to sequential Bell swaps with distinct heralding clicks.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n  \u201cDual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer with Spectral\u2010Selective Mixing\u201d  \n\nWe have two unknown Bell\u2010pairs encoded in two frequency bins f\u2081 and f\u2082:\n  \u2022 Pair\u2081 (f\u2081) on modes 0 & 1  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2082 (f\u2082) on modes 2 & 3  \n\nGoal: In one static interferometer, unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of Pair\u2081 AND simultaneously all four Bell states of Pair\u2082, using a minimal number of ancilla photons.\n\nSetup:\n  \u2013 Input qubits: modes 0,1 and modes 2,3  \n  \u2013 Ancilla photons: from four single\u2010photon emitters (modes 4\u20137)  \n  \u2013 Linear\u2010optical network: to be optimized by Pytheus, mixes all eight modes  \n  \u2013 8 photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors: d\u2080\u2026d\u2087  \n\nWe assign a unique 8\u2010click pattern (one click per detector) to each of the 16 possible Bell\u2010state combinations (4 states \u00d7 4 states). Successful heralding of a particular pattern tells us both the Bell outcome for Pair\u2081 and for Pair\u2082.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  single_emitters:   [4]  [5]  [6]  [7]         (ancilla photons)  \n  inputs:            [0]  [1]  [2]  [3]         (Bell\u2010pair photons)  \n  network:           [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]  \n  detectors:         [d0][d1][d2][d3][d4][d5][d6][d7]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Dual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer (two simultaneous BSMs)\",\n  foldername: \"dual_channel_BSA\",\n  in_nodes: [0,1,2,3],            # A click pattern unambiguously tells us the Bell outcome of both pairs.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  single_emitters:   [4]  [5]  [6]  [7]         (ancilla photons)  \n  inputs:            [0]  [1]  [2]  [3]         (Bell\u2010pair photons)  \n  network:           [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]  \n  detectors:         [d0][d1][d2][d3][d4][d5][d6][d7]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Dual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer (two simultaneous BSMs)\",\n  foldername:        \"dual_channel_BSA\",\n  in_nodes:          [0,1,2,3],            # It simply duplicates the well\u2010known 2\u2010ancilla, 4\u2010detector linear\u2010optical BSM (Grice 2011\u2010style) for each band within a single 8\u2010mode interferometer. By engineering spectral-selective ancilla connections (via removed_connections), the device heralds one of three entanglement\u2010swap primitives, depending on which subset of the three ancilla detectors fires:\n\n  Pattern P\u2081 (e.g. clicks on ancillas 4&5 only) \u21d2 \u201cHigh-Freq Swap\u201d  \n    \u2013 Entangle A\u2081\u2013D\u2081, leave A\u2082\u2013B\u2082 and C\u2082\u2013D\u2082 untouched.  \n\n  Pattern P\u2082 (clicks on ancillas 5&6 only) \u21d2 \u201cLow-Freq Swap\u201d  \n    \u2013 Entangle A\u2082\u2013D\u2082, leave A\u2081\u2013B\u2081 and C\u2081\u2013D\u2081 untouched.  \n\n  Pattern P\u2083 (clicks on ancillas 4&6 only) \u21d2 \u201cCross-Spectral Swap\u201d  \n    \u2013 Entangle A\u2081\u2013D\u2082 and A\u2082\u2013D\u2081 simultaneously.\n\nVisualization (left\u2192right, photons travel down):\n  pair_sources:   [A\u2081\u2013B\u2081]  [A\u2082\u2013B\u2082]  [C\u2081\u2013D\u2081]  [C\u2082\u2013D\u2082]  \n  ancillas:            [4]      [5]      [6]  \n  inputs to network:   [0]  [1]  [2]  [3]  \n                       (B\u2081) (B\u2082) (C\u2081) (C\u2082)  \n  network:             [   to be optimized by Pytheus   ]  \n  detectors:           [d0][d1][d2][d3]  (output modes)  \n  ancilla_detectors:   [a4][a5][a6]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Tri-Functional Spectral Swap Switch\",\n  foldername:        \"tri_spec_swap\",\n  in_nodes:          [0,1,2,3],            # ancilla 4,5 \u2194 high-freq inputs only\n    [4,2],[4,3],[5,2],[5,3],\n    # ancilla 5,6 \u2194 low-freq inputs only\n    [5,0],[5,3],[6,0],[6,3],\n    # ancilla 4,6 \u2194 cross-freq inputs only\n    [4,1],[4,3],[6,1],[6,3]\n  ],\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"--110\", result: \"high-freq swap\"},    # a4=0,a5=1,a6=1\n    {pattern: \"-1-01\", result: \"low-freq swap\"},     # a5=0,a6=1\n    {pattern: \"1--10\", result: \"cross-freq swap\"}    # a4=1,a6=0\n  ],\n  loss_func:       \"heralded_multi_swap\", # custom loss rewarding the three mapping patterns\n  optimizer:       \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:     50,\n  samples:         20,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 First static device implementing three distinct entanglement\u2010swap operations in one ancilla-assisted interferometer.  \n  \u2022 Encodes spectral tunability via \u201cplasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u201d\u2013inspired abstract beamsplitter selectivity, without active control.  \n  \u2022 Provides a template for N-outcome spectral swap routers\u2014crucial for multi-channel quantum-network architectures.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The proposed tri\u2010functional spectral swap switch is essentially a straightforward extension of the same ancilla-heralded, static linear-optical entanglement router/switch concepts already explored (including your earlier spectral routers and ensemble proposals). Simply adding a third heralding pattern to choose among high-freq, low-freq, or cross-freq swaps doesn\u2019t introduce a new interference mechanism, resource saving, or network capability beyond trivial multi-outcome relabeling. This fails to meet the threshold for a genuinely novel PRL-worthy quantum-optical primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To achieve genuine novelty, you would need to propose a qualitatively new routing primitive\u2014for example, a coherent superposition of multiple swap orders (indefinite causal order), ancilla-free multi-outcome routing, or a cross-domain interference effect that cannot be reduced to sequential Bell swaps with distinct click patterns."

    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: High-speed quantum radio-frequency-over-light communication\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Optimal function estimation with photonic quantum sensor networks\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Artificial stochastic neural network on the base of double quantum wells\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. THE FEEDBACK IS INCREDIBLE IMPORTANT !!! FOR SURE LOOK AT THEM AND UNDERSTAND THE CORE IDEA OF THEM!! YOU HAVE FAILED SO OFTEN BEFORE, FREAKING TAKE IT SERIOUS!\n\nSTART OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n<existing_feedback>\nEND OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n\nThis feedback is extremely important and very valuable information. It should be taken very seriously. Take it into account when coming up with your own idea. TAKE IT SERIOUS, THE FEEDBACK IS VERY IMPORTANT!!!!! BEFORE CREATING AN IDEA, THINK ABOUT WHETHER MY PREVIOUS FEEDBACK WOULD ALLOW IT!!!\n\nBe constructively critical of your own idea and check if it is novel. Refine it and aim for producing a truly novel idea.\n\nHere are the targets that pytheus has already designed quantum optics experiments for.  A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d into a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum network (focusing on entanglement swapping/teleportation rather than state generation):\n    a) Spectral\u2010selective entanglement\u2010swapping switch: a single static linear\u2010optical network that, depending on which ancilla detectors click, heralds entanglement swapping in one of two spectral channels (f\u2081 or f\u2082).\n    b) Frequency\u2010controlled teleportation gate: teleport one of two frequency\u2010encoded qubits through a Bell\u2010measurement network whose beamsplitter \u201cweights\u201d (abstractly tunable) derive from plasmonic tuning; the output port (one of two receivers) is chosen by ancilla clicks.\n    c) Multi\u2010channel repeater node: perform simultaneous entanglement swapping across N spectral bins in one device, then use ancilla patterns to collapse to a particular channel for routing.\n  Step 2: Evaluate novelty & feasibility:\n    a) Novel: no existing Pytheus example implements a single device that can herald swapping in either of two distinct spectral channels \u201con demand.\u201d Pytheus can handle ancilla\u2010assisted static networks with multiple heralding outcomes.\n    b) Teleportation\u2010router is similar to (a) but less clear as a pure swap: it mixes teleportation and routing, risking dynamic control.\n    c) Looks close to existing multiplexed\u2010swapping examples (ES_246), just more channels.\n  Step 3: Select (a), the Spectral\u2010Selective Swap Switch.\n  Step 4: Novelty:  \n    \u2013 Introduces a quantum\u2010network primitive: a static swap \u201cswitch\u201d that conditionally swaps entanglement in one of two frequency bins, heralded by distinct click patterns.  \n    \u2013 Goes beyond standard entanglement swapping by offering a binary choice of channels in one device.  \n    \u2013 Exploits spectral tunability conceptually (via abstract \u201ctunable beamsplitters\u201d) without requiring dynamic feedback.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n    \u2013 Purely linear\u2010optical, ancilla\u2010assisted, static network with probabilistic pair\u2010sources and single\u2010photon detectors.  \n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavity\u2010resonance modelling is needed\u2014Pytheus only optimizes an abstract mode\u2010mixing unitary.  \n    \u2013 Target is a network transformation (entanglement swapping), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cSpectral\u2010Selective Entanglement Swap Switch\u201d\nWe start with four Bell\u2010pairs in two spectral channels:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2081 (f\u2081): A\u2081\u2013B\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2082 (f\u2082): A\u2082\u2013B\u2082  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2083 (f\u2081): C\u2081\u2013D\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2084 (f\u2082): C\u2082\u2013D\u2082  \nTwo of the photons (B\u2081, C\u2081 in channel f\u2081 and B\u2082, C\u2082 in channel f\u2082) feed into a single static linear\u2010optical network together with two ancilla photons. Depending on which ancilla detectors fire, the device heralds one of two entanglement\u2010swapping operations:\n  \u2013 Pattern P\u2081 \u21d2 swap in f\u2081: entangle A\u2081\u2013D\u2081  \n  \u2013 Pattern P\u2082 \u21d2 swap in f\u2082: entangle A\u2082\u2013D\u2082  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n pair sources:  [pair] [pair] [pair] [pair]  \n ancillas:      [2]    [3]  \n inputs:        [0]    [1]    [4]    [5]  \n                (B\u2081)  (B\u2082)  (C\u2081)  (C\u2082)  \n network:       [to be optimized]  \n detectors:     [d\u2080][d\u2081][d\u2082][d\u2083]  \n\nConfig skeleton for Pytheus:\n{\n  description: \"Spectral\u2010Selective Entanglement Swap Switch\",\n  foldername: \"spec_swap_switch\",\n  in_nodes: [0,1,4,5],           # B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082\n  single_emitters: [],           # using probabilistic pair sources\n  num_anc: 2,                    # ancilla photons at nodes 2,3\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"1100\", result: \"swap f1\"},   # detectors d0 & d1 click\n    {pattern: \"0011\", result: \"swap f2\"}    # detectors d2 & d3 click\n  ],\n  loss_func: \"heralded_swap\",    # custom loss rewarding correct spectral\u2010swap mapping\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  samples: 30,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n\u2013 A first demonstration of a \u201cquantum swap switch\u201d that routes entanglement into one of two spectral modes via heralding, without any dynamic control.  \n\u2013 Bridges spectral tunability (conceptually via plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters) with entanglement\u2010swapping protocols.  \n\u2013 Provides a building block for spectrally multiplexed quantum networks and on\u2010demand entanglement routing.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to existing spectral\u2010mode entanglement routers (e.g. the \u201cHeralded Spectral\u2010Control Quantum Router\u201d and the hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic multiplexed entanglement router). A two\u2010pattern entanglement\u2010swap switch adds no fundamentally new interference or resource advantage. To be novel, you\u2019d need a qualitatively different routing primitive (e.g. multi\u2010outcome superposition, ancilla\u2010free operation, or a new form of mode\u2010entangling transformation) rather than a spectral relabeling of known Bell\u2010swap schemes.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Feasible: only linear optics, ancillas, static.  \n    b) Basis\u2010choice teleportation resembles routing plus teleportation, but risks dynamic control.  \n    c) Three\u2010outcome router is just an extension of two\u2010outcome spectral swap\u2014likely too close to existing multiplexed examples.  \n  Step 3: Pick (a).  \n  Step 4: Novelty:  \n    \u2013 Implements a \u201cswap switch\u201d that conditionally entangles in two distinct encodings\u2014frequency vs. time\u2014within one device.  \n    \u2013 Exploits spectral tunability (abstractly plasmonic\u2010nanocavity beamsplitter) to mix and separate both domains without dynamic elements.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n    \u2013 Define 4 input modes (B_f, B_t, C_f, C_t), 2 ancillas, a static linear\u2010optical network, and post\u2010selected heralding patterns.  \n    \u2013 No time\u2010dependent feedback, no forbidden state\u2010generation\u2014purely a network\u2010transformation target.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cDual\u2010Domain Entanglement Swap Switch\u201d\n\nWe prepare two Bell\u2010pairs in the frequency domain (f\u2081) and two Bell\u2010pairs in the time\u2010bin domain (early/late):\n  \u2022 Bell_f: A_f\u2013B_f  \n  \u2022 Bell_f: C_f\u2013D_f  \n  \u2022 Bell_t: A_t\u2013B_t  \n  \u2022 Bell_t: C_t\u2013D_t  \n\nAt the central node Bob, the four photons B_f,B_t,C_f,C_t enter a single static linear\u2010optical network together with two ancillary photons (from pair\u2010sources or single\u2010photon emitters). The network is optimized so that two distinct ancilla\u2010click patterns herald two different entanglement\u2010swapping operations:\n\n  Pattern Pf  \u21d2 Swap in frequency domain: entangle A_f\u2013D_f.  \n  Pattern Pt  \u21d2 Swap in time\u2010bin domain: entangle A_t\u2013D_t.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  pair-sources:  [pair] [pair] [pair] [pair]  \n  ancillas:      [2]    [3]  \n  inputs:        [0]    [1]    [4]    [5]  \n                 (B_f)  (B_t)  (C_f)  (C_t)  \n  network:       [ to be optimized ]  \n  detectors:     [d0][d1][d2][d3]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Dual\u2010Domain Entanglement Swap Switch\",\n  foldername: \"dual_domain_swap\",\n  in_nodes: [0,1,4,5],            # B_f, B_t, C_f, C_t\n  num_anc: 2,                     # ancillas at nodes 2,3\n  single_emitters: [],            # using probabilistic pair sources\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"1100\", result: \"frequency swap\"},  # d0 & d1 click\n    {pattern: \"0011\", result: \"time-bin swap\"}    # d2 & d3 click\n  ],\n  loss_func: \"heralded_swap\",      # custom loss rewarding correct domain-swap mapping\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  samples: 30,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 A true \u201cswap switch\u201d toggling between two distinct encodings\u2014frequency vs. time\u2014using one static, ancilla-assisted linear\u2010optical network.  \n  \u2022 Abstractly employs \u201ctunable beamsplitters\u201d (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity inspiration) to mix/separate spectral and temporal modes without active control.  \n  \u2022 Opens a new class of quantum\u2010network primitives: on-demand, multi\u2010domain entanglement routing\u2014extensible to more domains.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This idea is essentially identical in structure to the earlier spectral-mode swap router/switch schemes, merely substituting time-bins for one of the frequency channels. To be novel, you must propose a fundamentally new routing primitive\u2014e.g. ancilla-free domain selection, multi-outcome superpositions beyond two branches, or a crossed-domain interference effect that cannot be reduced to a standard Bell-swap router.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Feasible: static, ancilla\u2010assisted, purely linear optics, no feedback.  \n    b) Bell measurements are covered by known two\u2010ancilla schemes\u2014this just swaps degree of freedom.  \n    c) Three\u2010outcome router is a straightforward extension of prior two\u2010outcome routers\u2014unlikely novel enough.  \n  Step 3: Pick (a).  \n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    \u2013 Realizes three different entanglement\u2010swapping operations (swap in f\u2081, swap in f\u2082, two\u2010hop swap) in one static network.  \n    \u2013 Introduces the first \u201chierarchical entanglement repeater switch\u201d that conditionally chooses the number of hops and the spectral channel.  \n    \u2013 Leverages spectral\u2010selective beamsplitters (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity inspiration) abstractly without dynamic control.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    \u2013 Uses only probabilistic pair sources, ancilla single photons, linear\u2010optical mixing, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n    \u2013 No active feedback or cavity modelling is required\u2014Pytheus optimizes an abstract unitary on six modes and four ancillas.  \n    \u2013 Targets a network transformation (entanglement routing), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cSpectral-Multiplexed Hierarchical Entanglement Switch\u201d\n\nWe begin with three Bell\u2010pairs:\n  \u2022 Pair\u2081 in channel f\u2081: A\u2013B  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2082 in channel f\u2082: C\u2013D  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2083 in channel f\u2081: E\u2013F  \n\nAt the central node we feed photons B,C,D,E into one static linear\u2010optical network, together with four ancilla photons. By engineering ancilla coupling to be spectral\u2010selective (abstractly via removed_connections), different ancilla\u2010click patterns herald three distinct entanglement\u2010swapping operations:\n\n  1. One-hop swap in f\u2081 (ancillas 1&2 click) \u2192 entangle A\u2013C.  \n  2. One-hop swap in f\u2082 (ancillas 3&4 click) \u2192 entangle C\u2013F.  \n  3. Two-hop swap across f\u2081\u2192f\u2082 (all four ancillas click) \u2192 entangle A\u2013F.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n pair\u2010sources:   [pair_f1]  [pair_f2]  [pair_f1]\n                A\u21920      C\u21922      E\u21924\n                B\u21921      D\u21923      F\u21925\n\n ancilla sources:         [6]  [7]  [8]  [9]\n\n inputs to network:       [1][2][3][4]  (B,C,D,E)\n\n network:                 [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]\n\n detectors:               [d0][d1][d2][d3]  (monitor 1\u20134)\n\n ancilla detectors:       [d4][d5][d6][d7]  (monitor 6\u20139)\n\nConfig skeleton for Pytheus:\n{\n  description: \"Spectral-Multiplexed Hierarchical Entanglement Switch\",\n  foldername: \"spec_multihop_swap\",\n  in_nodes: [1,2,3,4],            # B,C,D,E\n  num_anc: 4,                     # ancilla photons at modes 6\u20139\n  single_emitters: [],            # using probabilistic pair sources\n  removed_connections: [\n    # ancillas 6,7 only connect to B(1) & C(2): f\u2081\u2010swap\n    [6,3],[6,4],[7,3],[7,4],\n    # ancillas 8,9 only connect to D(3) & E(4): f\u2082\u2010swap\n    [8,1],[8,2],[9,1],[9,2]\n  ],\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"1100----\", result: \"swap f1 (A\u2013C)\"},\n    {pattern: \"0011----\", result: \"swap f2 (C\u2013F)\"},\n    {pattern: \"1111----\", result: \"two-hop swap (A\u2013F)\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func: \"heralded_multi_swap\",  # custom loss rewarding correct multi-outcome swaps\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  samples: 20,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy this is exciting:\n  \u2022 First demonstration of a \u201cquantum repeater switch\u201d that conditionally performs different numbers of entanglement\u2010swap hops and selectively operates in two spectral channels\u2014all in one static, ancilla-assisted network.  \n  \u2022 Abstractly captures the concept of spectral tunability via plasmonic\u2010cavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters without dynamic control.  \n  \u2022 Lays the groundwork for hierarchical, multiplexed quantum\u2010network routing\u2014immediately extensible to more channels or more hops.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal does not offer a fundamentally new photonic primitive beyond existing ancilla-assisted spectral entanglement routers or multi-outcome swap schemes. To reach PRL level novelty, you would need to identify an unprecedented interference effect (e.g. coherent superposition of swap orders), remove the ancilla-overhead scaling with outcome count, or demonstrate a routing primitive that cannot be reduced to sequential Bell swaps with different heralding patterns.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! \u21d2 feasible.\n    b) Too close to prior multiplexed routers (ES_246 style).\n    c) Novel but network\u2010coding at this level reduces to sequential swaps\u2014falls back to known swap schemes.\n Bridges spectral\u2010tunability concepts (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2013style, frequency\u2010selective beamsplitters) with measurement\u2010device capabilities.  \n    \u2013 Immediately generalizable to N parallel channels\u2014key for high\u2010throughput quantum networks.\n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    \u2013 Uses only probabilistic pair sources or single\u2010photon emitters for ancillas, a static linear\u2010optical unitary (to be optimized by Pytheus), and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavity\u2010resonance modelling needed\u2014Pytheus works at the abstract unitary level.  \n    \u2013 Clearly a network transformation (Bell measurements), not prohibited state generation.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cDual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer with Spectral\u2010Selective Mixing\u201d  \n\nWe have two unknown Bell\u2010pairs encoded in two frequency bins f\u2081 and f\u2082:\n  \u2022 Pair\u2081 (f\u2081) on modes 0 & 1  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2082 (f\u2082) on modes 2 & 3  \n\nGoal: In one static interferometer, unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of Pair\u2081 AND simultaneously all four Bell states of Pair\u2082, using a minimal number of ancilla photons.\n\nSetup:\n  \u2013 Input qubits: modes 0,1 and modes 2,3  \n  \u2013 Ancilla photons: from four single\u2010photon emitters (modes 4\u20137)  \n  \u2013 Linear\u2010optical network: to be optimized by Pytheus, mixes all eight modes  \n  \u2013 8 photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors: d\u2080\u2026d\u2087  \n\nWe assign a unique 8\u2010click pattern (one click per detector) to each of the 16 possible Bell\u2010state combinations (4 states \u00d7 4 states). Successful heralding of a particular pattern tells us both the Bell outcome for Pair\u2081 and for Pair\u2082.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  single_emitters:   [4]  [5]  [6]  [7]         (ancilla photons)  \n  inputs:            [0]  [1]  [2]  [3]         (Bell\u2010pair photons)  \n  network:           [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]  \n  detectors:         [d0][d1][d2][d3][d4][d5][d6][d7]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Dual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer (two simultaneous BSMs)\",\n  foldername: \"dual_channel_BSA\",\n  in_nodes: [0,1,2,3],            # the two unknown Bell\u2010pairs\n  single_emitters: [4,5,6,7],     # four ancilla photons\n  num_anc: 4,\n  removed_connections: [],        # allow full mixing\n  target_heralding: [             # map each 8\u2010bit click pattern to the 16 Bell outcomes\n    {pattern: \"11110000\", result: \"\u03a6+_f1 & \u03a6+_f2\"},\n    {pattern: \"11100001\", result: \"\u03a6+_f1 & \u03a6\u2013_f2\"},\n    \u2026                              # all 16 combinations\n    {pattern: \"00001111\", result: \"\u03a8\u2013_f1 & \u03a8\u2013_f2\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func: \"complete_bsa\",       # custom loss rewarding 1:1 mapping between patterns & Bell pairs\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 60,\n  samples: 40,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 A first demonstration of \u201cBell\u2010measurement multiplexing\u201d\u2014simultaneous unambiguous Bell\u2010state discrimination on two independent qubit\u2010pairs in a single static device.  \n  \u2022 Exploits spectral\u2010tunability notions (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2013style spectral beamsplitters) to isolate frequency bins f\u2081,f\u2082 within one unitary network.  \n  \u2022 Key building block for high\u2010rate, multi\u2010channel quantum\u2010key\u2010distribution (MDI\u2010QKD), multi\u2010mode repeater nodes, and parallel quantum\u2010network protocols.  \n  \u2022 Readily generalizable to N\u2010channel Bell\u2010measurement multiplexing by adding ancillas and detectors.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To make this idea PRL\u2010worthy, you would need to show a genuine multiplexing advantage\u2014for instance, achieving two simultaneous complete BSMs with fewer than four ancillas or eight detectors, harnessing cross\u2010channel interference to reduce resource count, or uncovering a brand\u2010new interference/correlation effect that cannot be decomposed into two parallel Bell measurements.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201cspectral tunability\u201d + \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network transformation:\n  a) Dual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer: one static interferometer that, with ancillas and spectral\u2010selective beamsplitters (plasmonic\u2010cavity inspiration), concurrently discriminates two independent Bell\u2010pairs encoded in two frequency bins.  \n  b) Hierarchical Spectral Swap Switch: one device that heralds three distinct entanglement\u2010swap outcomes (swap in f\u2081, swap in f\u2082, or two\u2010hop cross\u2010swap) by different ancilla clicks.  \n  c) Multi\u2010Outcome Teleportation Router: a network that teleports one qubit into one of three receivers based on which ancilla detectors fire, each mapped to a different spectral channel.\n\nStep 2: Evaluate novelty & feasibility:\n  a) No existing Pytheus experiment does parallel, unambiguous Bell\u2010state measurements on two channels. Purely linear\u2010optical, ancilla\u2010assisted, static \u2192 feasible.  \n  b) Too close to prior swap\u2010router proposals.  \n  c) Straightforward extension of two\u2010outcome routers \u2192 unlikely PRL\u2010worthy.\n\nStep 3: Select (a).\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\n  \u2013 Introduces \u201cBell\u2010measurement multiplexing\u201d: simultaneous, fully unambiguous Bell\u2010state discrimination on two frequency\u2010encoded qubit\u2010pairs in a single device.  \n  \u2013 Bridges spectral\u2010tunability (plasmonic\u2010cavity\u2013style spectral beamsplitters) with high\u2010throughput network measurements.  \n  \u2013 Directly generalizable to N\u2010channel multiplexing\u2014key to scalable quantum networks.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n  \u2013 Only uses probabilistic pair\u2010sources or single\u2010photon ancillas, a static interferometer (abstract unitary), and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavity modelling; Pytheus optimizes the mixing unitary on eight modes.  \n  \u2013 Clearly a network measurement primitive (Bell\u2010state analysis), not forbidden state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cDual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer with Spectral\u2010Selective Mixing\u201d\n\nWe have two unknown Bell\u2010pairs encoded in two spectral bins f\u2081 and f\u2082:\n  \u2022 Pair\u2081 (f\u2081) on modes 0 & 1  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2082 (f\u2082) on modes 2 & 3  \n\nGoal: In one static linear\u2010optical network, unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of Pair\u2081 AND simultaneously all four Bell states of Pair\u2082, using the minimal ancilla overhead.\n\nSetup:\n  \u2013 Input modes 0,1 (Pair\u2081) and 2,3 (Pair\u2082).  \n  \u2013 Four ancilla single photons (modes 4\u20137).  \n  \u2013 A linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus) mixing all eight modes.  \n  \u2013 Eight photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors d\u2080\u2026d\u2087.\n\nWe assign a unique 8\u2010click pattern (one click per detector) to each of the 16 Bell\u2010state combinations (4 states \u00d7 4 states). A click pattern unambiguously tells us the Bell outcome of both pairs.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  single_emitters:   [4]  [5]  [6]  [7]         (ancilla photons)  \n  inputs:            [0]  [1]  [2]  [3]         (Bell\u2010pair photons)  \n  network:           [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]  \n  detectors:         [d0][d1][d2][d3][d4][d5][d6][d7]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Dual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer (two simultaneous BSMs)\",\n  foldername:        \"dual_channel_BSA\",\n  in_nodes:          [0,1,2,3],            # two unknown Bell\u2010pairs\n  single_emitters:   [4,5,6,7],            # four ancilla photons\n  num_anc:           4,\n  removed_connections: [],                  # allow full mixing\n  target_heralding: [                       # all 16 combinations\n    {pattern: \"00001111\", result: \"\u03a8\u2013_f1 & \u03a8\u2013_f2\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func:         \"complete_bsa\",        # custom loss rewarding a one\u2010to\u2010one mapping of patterns\u2192Bell outcomes\n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:       60,\n  samples:           40,\n  number_resolving:  True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2013 Enables \u201cBell\u2010measurement multiplexing,\u201d doubling the throughput of Bell\u2010state analysis per device.  \n  \u2013 Leverages spectral tunability via plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters (abstract mode\u2010mixers) to isolate and analyze two frequency bins in one network.  \n  \u2013 Essential for high\u2010rate, parallel quantum\u2010key\u2010distribution (MDI\u2010QKD), multi\u2010mode repeaters, and scalable quantum networks.  \n  \u2013 Straightforwardly generalizable to N\u2010channel multiplexing by adding ancillas and detectors.\n\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To make this idea worthy of further consideration, you would need to demonstrate a genuine multiplexing advantage\u2014for example by using cross\u2010channel interference to halve the ancilla count or detector number, or by harnessing a new quantum interference phenomenon that simultaneously discriminates both Bell pairs with strictly fewer resources than two standalone analyzers.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought: \n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to marry \u201cspectral tunability\u201d + \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d in a network\u2010transformation (swap/teleportation) setting:\n    a) Tri-Functional Spectral Swap Switch: one static ancilla-assisted interferometer that, via three distinct heralding patterns, implements three entanglement\u2010swap primitives\u2014swap in high-frequency channel, swap in low-frequency channel, or cross-spectral swap.\n    b) Spectral-Mode Quantum Switch (indefinite causal order): a single network that, conditioned on ancilla clicks, applies either \u201cswap then identity\u201d or \u201cidentity then swap\u201d in superposition\u2014realizing an indefinite\u2010order swap switch.\n    c) Multiplexed Bell-Swap Cascade: perform two sequential entanglement-swaps on two spectral channels in one device and herald which swap succeeded first via ancilla clicks, enabling a heralded \u201cwhich-path\u201d entanglement routing.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    a) No existing Pytheus experiment has more than two heralded swap outcomes. A three-outcome swap switch is a genuinely new routing primitive, purely static, ancilla-assisted linear optics => feasible.\n    b) Indefinite causal\u2010order devices are conceptually striking but require encoding a control qubit and genuine superpositions\u2014Pytheus cannot handle coherent control feedback and DOF beyond mode mixing.\n    c) Essentially two back-to-back swaps with heralding \u2013 close to standard multiplexed swap schemes.\n  Step 3: Pick (a).\n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    \u2013 Introduces the first tri-functional entanglement-swap router: a single static network that can herald three qualitatively distinct swap operations\u2014two channel-preserving swaps plus a cross-channel swap\u2014without any dynamic feedback.\n    \u2013 Conceptually leverages \u201cspectral tunability\u201d (plasmonic-cavity\u2013inspired beamsplitter selectivity) abstractly in the mode-mixing unitary.\n    \u2013 Generalizes immediate to N-outcome multiplexed swap routers.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2013 Inputs: four photons from two Bell pairs in two spectral bins.\n    \u2013 Ancillas: three additional photons (pair sources or single emitters).\n    \u2013 Static linear network \u2192 detectors.\n    \u2013 Three heralding click\u2010patterns mapped to three swap outcomes.\n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback, no forbidden state\u2010generation, all within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical, ancilla-assisted framework.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cTri-Functional Spectral Swap Switch\u201d\n\nWe prepare two Bell pairs in two spectral channels:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2081 (f_high): A\u2081\u2013B\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2082 (f_low): A\u2082\u2013B\u2082  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2083 (f_high): C\u2081\u2013D\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2084 (f_low): C\u2082\u2013D\u2082  \n\nAt the central station we feed B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082 (modes 0\u20133) into one static linear-optical network, together with three ancilla photons (modes 4\u20136). By engineering spectral-selective ancilla connections (via removed_connections), the device heralds one of three entanglement\u2010swap primitives, depending on which subset of the three ancilla detectors fires:\n\n  Pattern P\u2081 (e.g. clicks on ancillas 4&5 only) \u21d2 \u201cHigh-Freq Swap\u201d  \n    \u2013 Entangle A\u2081\u2013D\u2081, leave A\u2082\u2013B\u2082 and C\u2082\u2013D\u2082 untouched.  \n\n  Pattern P\u2082 (clicks on ancillas 5&6 only) \u21d2 \u201cLow-Freq Swap\u201d  \n    \u2013 Entangle A\u2082\u2013D\u2082, leave A\u2081\u2013B\u2081 and C\u2081\u2013D\u2081 untouched.  \n\n  Pattern P\u2083 (clicks on ancillas 4&6 only) \u21d2 \u201cCross-Spectral Swap\u201d  \n    \u2013 Entangle A\u2081\u2013D\u2082 and A\u2082\u2013D\u2081 simultaneously.\n\nVisualization (left\u2192right, photons travel down):\n  pair_sources:   [A\u2081\u2013B\u2081]  [A\u2082\u2013B\u2082]  [C\u2081\u2013D\u2081]  [C\u2082\u2013D\u2082]  \n  ancillas:            [4]      [5]      [6]  \n  inputs to network:   [0]  [1]  [2]  [3]  \n                       (B\u2081) (B\u2082) (C\u2081) (C\u2082)  \n  network:             [   to be optimized by Pytheus   ]  \n  detectors:           [d0][d1][d2][d3]  (output modes)  \n  ancilla_detectors:   [a4][a5][a6]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Tri-Functional Spectral Swap Switch\",\n  foldername:        \"tri_spec_swap\",\n  in_nodes:          [0,1,2,3],            # B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082\n  num_anc:           3,                    # ancilla modes 4\u20136\n  single_emitters:   [],                   # using probabilistic pair sources\n  removed_connections: [\n    # ancilla 4,5 \u2194 high-freq inputs only\n    [4,2],[4,3],[5,2],[5,3],\n    # ancilla 5,6 \u2194 low-freq inputs only\n    [5,0],[5,3],[6,0],[6,3],\n    # ancilla 4,6 \u2194 cross-freq inputs only\n    [4,1],[4,3],[6,1],[6,3]\n  ],\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"--110\", result: \"high-freq swap\"},    # a4=0,a5=1,a6=1\n    {pattern: \"-1-01\", result: \"low-freq swap\"},     # a5=0,a6=1\n    {pattern: \"1--10\", result: \"cross-freq swap\"}    # a4=1,a6=0\n  ],\n  loss_func:       \"heralded_multi_swap\", # custom loss rewarding the three mapping patterns\n  optimizer:       \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:     50,\n  samples:         20,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 First static device implementing three distinct entanglement\u2010swap operations in one ancilla-assisted interferometer.  \n  \u2022 Encodes spectral tunability via \u201cplasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u201d\u2013inspired abstract beamsplitter selectivity, without active control.  \n  \u2022 Provides a template for N-outcome spectral swap routers\u2014crucial for multi-channel quantum-network architectures.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To achieve genuine novelty, you would need to propose a qualitatively new routing primitive\u2014for example, a coherent superposition of multiple swap orders (indefinite causal order), ancilla-free multi-outcome routing, or a cross-domain interference effect that cannot be reduced to sequential Bell swaps with distinct click patterns.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to combine \u201cspectral tunability\u201d + \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d in a network transformation (focusing on entanglement swapping or teleportation, not state generation):\n    a) Single-Ancilla Multi-Outcome Spectral Swap Router: one ancilla photon plus a static, spectrally selective interferometer heralds three distinct swap operations (high-freq, low-freq, cross-freq) via three detection modes.\n    b) Ancilla-Free Dual-Frequency Swap via Cross-Interference: use four-photon interference alone (no ancilla) to swap entanglement in either f\u2081 or f\u2082, heralded by which pair of detectors fire\u2014leveraging plasmonic-like spectral beamsplitters.\n    c) Frequency-Controlled Gate Teleportation: teleport a two-qubit gate (e.g. CZ) on frequency-encoded qubits, choosing between two spectral channels by ancilla clicks.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    a) Novel: reduces ancilla overhead to one for three swap-outcomes; purely linear-optical, static, ancilla-assisted \u2192 feasible in Pytheus.\n    b) Ancilla-free swap is likely impossible with passive linear optics alone (50% limit), so not feasible.\n    c) Gate teleportation is complex and involves input unknown states \u2192 Pytheus can\u2019t handle unknown inputs.\n  Step 3: Select (a).\n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    \u2013 First proposal for a multi-outcome entanglement-swap router using a single ancilla photon.  \n    \u2013 Exploits \u201cspectral tunability\u201d conceptually via plasmonic-nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters that selectively couple ancilla to different frequency modes.  \n    \u2013 Yields three qualitatively different swap operations from one static device, a new quantum-network primitive.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2013 Inputs: B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082 from two Bell pairs in f\u2081,f\u2082.  \n    \u2013 One ancilla single-photon emitter.  \n    \u2013 Static linear-optical network to be optimized.  \n    \u2013 Three ancilla detectors map to three heralded swap outcomes.  \n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback, no forbidden state generation, all within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical, ancilla-assisted framework.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cSingle-Ancilla Multi-Outcome Spectral Swap Router\u201d\n\nWe start with two Bell pairs in two frequency bins:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2081 (f\u2081): A\u2081\u2013B\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2082 (f\u2082): A\u2082\u2013B\u2082  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2083 (f\u2081): C\u2081\u2013D\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2084 (f\u2082): C\u2082\u2013D\u2082  \n\nGoal: A single static interferometer, using exactly one ancilla photon, heralds three different entanglement\u2010swap operations\u2014high-frequency swap, low-frequency swap, or cross-frequency swap\u2014via which detector clicks.\n\nSetup:\n  \u2013 Input modes: B\u2081 (mode 0), B\u2082 (1), C\u2081 (2), C\u2082 (3)  \n  \u2013 Ancilla: single-photon emitter at mode 4  \n  \u2013 Linear-optical network: to be optimized by Pytheus (abstract \u201ctunable beamsplitters\u201d inspired by plasmonic nanocavities)  \n  \u2013 Detectors: d\u2080\u2026d\u2083 on the four output modes; ancilla detectors a\u2084,a\u2085,a\u2086 on three distinct ancilla output paths\n\nHeralded outcomes:\n  1. Ancilla click at a\u2084 \u21d2 High-Freq Swap: entangle A\u2081\u2013D\u2081  \n  2. Ancilla click at a\u2085 \u21d2 Low-Freq Swap: entangle A\u2082\u2013D\u2082  \n  3. Ancilla click at a\u2086 \u21d2 Cross-Freq Swap: entangle A\u2081\u2013D\u2082 & A\u2082\u2013D\u2081\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  pair\u2010sources:   [A\u2081\u2013B\u2081]  [A\u2082\u2013B\u2082]  [C\u2081\u2013D\u2081]  [C\u2082\u2013D\u2082]  \n  ancilla emitter:[    4    ]  \n  inputs to net:  [0]    [1]    [2]    [3]  \n                 (B\u2081)  (B\u2082)  (C\u2081)  (C\u2082)  \n  network:       [   to be optimized by Pytheus   ]  \n  detectors:     [d\u2080][d\u2081][d\u2082][d\u2083]  \n  ancilla det.:  [a\u2084][a\u2085][a\u2086]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Single-Ancilla Multi-Outcome Spectral Swap Router\",\n  foldername:        \"single_ancilla_spec_swap\",\n  in_nodes:          [0,1,2,3],           # B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082\n  single_emitters:   [4],                 # one ancilla photon\n  num_anc:           1,\n  removed_connections: [\n    # control which inputs the ancilla can mix with for each detector outcome:\n    # ancilla path 4 mixes only with f\u2081-modes 0,2\n    [4,1],[4,3],\n    # ancilla path 5 mixes only with f\u2082-modes 1,3\n    [4,0],[4,2]\n    # ancilla path 6 mixes with all four for cross-swap\n  ],\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"----1--\", result: \"high-freq swap\"},   # a4 clicks\n    {pattern: \"-----1-\", result: \"low-freq swap\"},    # a5 clicks\n    {pattern: \"------1\", result: \"cross-freq swap\"}   # a6 clicks\n  ],\n  loss_func:         \"heralded_swap_multi\", # custom loss rewarding the three correct mappings\n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:       40,\n  samples:           25,\n  number_resolving:  True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 Achieves three heralded swap operations in one static device using only one ancilla photon\u2014a resource saving over one-ancilla-per-outcome schemes.  \n  \u2022 Conceptually employs \u201cspectral tunability\u201d via plasmonic-nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters that selectively couple ancilla to different frequency modes.  \n  \u2022 Introduces a new quantum-network primitive\u2014multi-outcome entanglement-swap routing with minimal ancilla overhead\u2014extensible to more channels and outcomes."
