In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). C\u2081\u2013D\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2084 (f\u2082): C\u2082\u2013D\u2082  \nTwo of the photons (B\u2081, C\u2081 in channel f\u2081 and B\u2082, C\u2082 in channel f\u2082) feed into a single static linear\u2010optical network together with two ancilla photons. Depending on which ancilla detectors fire, the device heralds one of two entanglement\u2010swapping operations:\n  \u2013 Pattern P\u2081 \u21d2 swap in f\u2081: entangle A\u2081\u2013D\u2081  \n  \u2013 Pattern P\u2082 \u21d2 swap in f\u2082: entangle A\u2082\u2013D\u2082  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n pair sources:  [pair] [pair] [pair] [pair]  \n ancillas:      [2]    [3]  \n inputs:        [0]    [1]    [4]    [5]  \n                (B\u2081)  (B\u2082)  (C\u2081)  (C\u2082)  \n network:       [to be optimized]  \n detectors:     [d\u2080][d\u2081][d\u2082][d\u2083]  \n\nConfig skeleton for Pytheus:\n{\n  description: \"Spectral\u2010Selective Entanglement Swap Switch\",\n  foldername: \"spec_swap_switch\",\n  in_nodes: [0,1,4,5],           # B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082\n  single_emitters: [],           # using probabilistic pair sources\n  num_anc: 2,                    # ancilla photons at nodes 2,3\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"1100\", result: \"swap f1\"},   # detectors d0 & d1 click\n    {pattern: \"0011\", result: \"swap f2\"}    # detectors d2 & d3 click\n  ],\n  loss_func: \"heralded_swap\",    # custom loss rewarding correct spectral\u2010swap mapping\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  samples: 30,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n\u2013 A first demonstration of a \u201cquantum swap switch\u201d that routes entanglement into one of two spectral modes via heralding, without any dynamic control.  \n\u2013 Bridges spectral tunability (conceptually via plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters) with entanglement\u2010swapping protocols.  \n\u2013 Provides a building block for spectrally multiplexed quantum networks and on\u2010demand entanglement routing.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to existing spectral\u2010mode entanglement routers (e.g. the \u201cHeralded Spectral\u2010Control Quantum Router\u201d and the hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic multiplexed entanglement router). A two\u2010pattern entanglement\u2010swap switch adds no fundamentally new interference or resource advantage. To be novel, you\u2019d need a qualitatively different routing primitive (e.g. multi\u2010outcome superposition, ancilla\u2010free operation, or a new form of mode\u2010entangling transformation) rather than a spectral relabeling of known Bell\u2010swap schemes.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought: \n  Step 1: Brainstorm 3 novel Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to combine \u201cspectral tunability\u201d and \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d in a quantum\u2010network transformation (swap/teleportation)  \n    a) Dual\u2010domain entanglement\u2010swap switch: in one static network, herald swapping either in the frequency domain or in the time\u2010bin domain, chosen by ancilla clicks.  \n    b) Frequency\u2010selective teleportation with basis choice: teleport a frequency\u2010encoded qubit in one of two spectral bases (f\u2081/f\u2082) depending on which ancilla fires.  \n    c) Spectral\u2010mode entanglement router with multi\u2010outcome superposition: a single network heralds one of three different entanglement\u2010swapping configurations across three spectral channels.  \n  Step 2: Assess novelty & Pytheus feasibility  \n    a) Dual\u2010domain swap switch is new: no prior Pytheus experiment toggles between different degrees of freedom in one device. Feasible: only linear optics, ancillas, static.  \n    b) Basis\u2010choice teleportation resembles routing plus teleportation, but risks dynamic control.  \n    c) Three\u2010outcome router is just an extension of two\u2010outcome spectral swap\u2014likely too close to existing multiplexed examples.  \n  Step 3: Pick (a).  \n  Step 4: Novelty:  \n    \u2013 Implements a \u201cswap switch\u201d that conditionally entangles in two distinct encodings\u2014frequency vs. time\u2014within one device.  \n    \u2013 Exploits spectral tunability (abstractly plasmonic\u2010nanocavity beamsplitter) to mix and separate both domains without dynamic elements.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n    \u2013 Define 4 input modes (B_f, B_t, C_f, C_t), 2 ancillas, a static linear\u2010optical network, and post\u2010selected heralding patterns.  \n    \u2013 No time\u2010dependent feedback, no forbidden state\u2010generation\u2014purely a network\u2010transformation target.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cDual\u2010Domain Entanglement Swap Switch\u201d\n\nWe prepare two Bell\u2010pairs in the frequency domain (f\u2081) and two Bell\u2010pairs in the time\u2010bin domain (early/late):\n  \u2022 Bell_f: A_f\u2013B_f  \n  \u2022 Bell_f: C_f\u2013D_f  \n  \u2022 Bell_t: A_t\u2013B_t  \n  \u2022 Bell_t: C_t\u2013D_t  \n\nAt the central node Bob, the four photons B_f,B_t,C_f,C_t enter a single static linear\u2010optical network together with two ancillary photons (from pair\u2010sources or single\u2010photon emitters). The network is optimized so that two distinct ancilla\u2010click patterns herald two different entanglement\u2010swapping operations:\n\n  Pattern Pf  \u21d2 Swap in frequency domain: entangle A_f\u2013D_f.  \n  Pattern Pt  \u21d2 Swap in time\u2010bin domain: entangle A_t\u2013D_t.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  pair-sources:  [pair] [pair] [pair] [pair]  \n  ancillas:      [2]    [3]  \n  inputs:        [0]    [1]    [4]    [5]  \n                 (B_f)  (B_t)  (C_f)  (C_t)  \n  network:       [ to be optimized ]  \n  detectors:     [d0][d1][d2][d3]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Dual\u2010Domain Entanglement Swap Switch\",\n  foldername: \"dual_domain_swap\",\n  in_nodes: [0,1,4,5],            # B_f, B_t, C_f, C_t\n  num_anc: 2,                     # ancillas at nodes 2,3\n  single_emitters: [],            # using probabilistic pair sources\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"1100\", result: \"frequency swap\"},  # d0 & d1 click\n    {pattern: \"0011\", result: \"time-bin swap\"}    # d2 & d3 click\n  ],\n  loss_func: \"heralded_swap\",      # custom loss rewarding correct domain-swap mapping\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  samples: 30,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 A true \u201cswap switch\u201d toggling between two distinct encodings\u2014frequency vs. time\u2014using one static, ancilla-assisted linear\u2010optical network.  \n  \u2022 Abstractly employs \u201ctunable beamsplitters\u201d (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity inspiration) to mix/separate spectral and temporal modes without active control.  \n  \u2022 Opens a new class of quantum\u2010network primitives: on-demand, multi\u2010domain entanglement routing\u2014extensible to more domains.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This idea is essentially identical in structure to the earlier spectral-mode swap router/switch schemes, merely substituting time-bins for one of the frequency channels. To be novel, you must propose a fundamentally new routing primitive\u2014e.g. ancilla-free domain selection, multi-outcome superpositions beyond two branches, or a crossed-domain interference effect that cannot be reduced to a standard Bell-swap router.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Feasible: static, ancilla\u2010assisted, purely linear optics, no feedback.  \n    b) Bell measurements are covered by known two\u2010ancilla schemes\u2014this just swaps degree of freedom.  \n    c) Three\u2010outcome router is a straightforward extension of prior two\u2010outcome routers\u2014unlikely novel enough.  \n  Step 3: Pick (a).  \n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    \u2013 Realizes three different entanglement\u2010swapping operations (swap in f\u2081, swap in f\u2082, two\u2010hop swap) in one static network.  \n    \u2013 Introduces the first \u201chierarchical entanglement repeater switch\u201d that conditionally chooses the number of hops and the spectral channel.  \n    \u2013 Leverages spectral\u2010selective beamsplitters (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity inspiration) abstractly without dynamic control.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    \u2013 Uses only probabilistic pair sources, ancilla single photons, linear\u2010optical mixing, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n    \u2013 No active feedback or cavity modelling is required\u2014Pytheus optimizes an abstract unitary on six modes and four ancillas.  \n    \u2013 Targets a network transformation (entanglement routing), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cSpectral-Multiplexed Hierarchical Entanglement Switch\u201d\n\nWe begin with three Bell\u2010pairs:\n  \u2022 Pair\u2081 in channel f\u2081: A\u2013B  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2082 in channel f\u2082: C\u2013D  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2083 in channel f\u2081: E\u2013F  \n\nAt the central node we feed photons B,C,D,E into one static linear\u2010optical network, together with four ancilla photons. By engineering ancilla coupling to be spectral\u2010selective (abstractly via removed_connections), different ancilla\u2010click patterns herald three distinct entanglement\u2010swapping operations:\n\n  1. One-hop swap in f\u2081 (ancillas 1&2 click) \u2192 entangle A\u2013C.  \n  2. One-hop swap in f\u2082 (ancillas 3&4 click) \u2192 entangle C\u2013F.  \n  3. B,C,D,E\n  num_anc: 4,                     # ancilla photons at modes 6\u20139\n  single_emitters: [],            # using probabilistic pair sources\n  removed_connections: [\n    # ancillas 6,7 only connect to B(1) & C(2): f\u2081\u2010swap\n    [6,3],[6,4],[7,3],[7,4],\n    # custom loss rewarding correct multi-outcome swaps\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  samples: 20,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy this is exciting:\n  \u2022 First demonstration of a \u201cquantum repeater switch\u201d that conditionally performs different numbers of entanglement\u2010swap hops and selectively operates in two spectral channels\u2014all in one static, ancilla-assisted network.  \n  \u2022 Abstractly captures the concept of spectral tunability via plasmonic\u2010cavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters without dynamic control.  \n  \u2022 Lays the groundwork for hierarchical, multiplexed quantum\u2010network routing\u2014immediately extensible to more channels or more hops.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal does not offer a fundamentally new photonic primitive beyond existing ancilla-assisted spectral entanglement routers or multi-outcome swap schemes. measurements simultaneously on two independent frequency\u2010encoded qubit pairs.\n    b) Frequency\u2010Multiplexed Teleportation Router: one device that teleports one of N spectral\u2010bin qubits \u21d2 feasible.\n    b) Too close to prior multiplexed routers (ES_246 style).\n    c) Novel but network\u2010coding at this level reduces to sequential swaps\u2014falls back to known swap schemes.\n needed\u2014Pytheus works at the abstract unitary level.  \n    \u2013 Clearly a network transformation (Bell measurements), not prohibited state generation.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction f\u2082:\n  \u2022 Pair\u2081 (f\u2081) on modes 0 & 1  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2082 (f\u2082) on modes 2 & 3  \n\nGoal: In one static interferometer, unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of Pair\u2081 AND simultaneously all four Bell states of Pair\u2082, using a minimal number of ancilla photons.\n\nSetup:\n  \u2013 Input qubits: modes 0,1 and modes 2,3  \n  \u2013 Ancilla photons: from four single\u2010photon emitters (modes 4\u20137)  \n  \u2013 Linear\u2010optical network: to be optimized by Pytheus, mixes all eight modes  \n  \u2013 8 photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors: d\u2080\u2026d\u2087  \n\nWe assign a unique 8\u2010click pattern (one click per detector) to each of the 16 possible Bell\u2010state combinations (4 states \u00d7 4 states). Successful heralding of a particular pattern tells us both the Bell outcome for Pair\u2081 and for Pair\u2082.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  single_emitters:   [4]  [5]  [6]  [7]         (ancilla photons)  \n  inputs:            [0]  [1]  [2]  [3]         (Bell\u2010pair photons)  \n  network:           [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]  \n  detectors:         [d0][d1][d2][d3][d4][d5][d6][d7]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Dual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer (two simultaneous BSMs)\",\n  foldername: \"dual_channel_BSA\",\n  in_nodes: [0,1,2,3],            # the two unknown Bell\u2010pairs\n  single_emitters: [4,5,6,7],     # four ancilla photons\n  num_anc: 4,\n  removed_connections: [],        # allow full mixing\n  target_heralding: [             # map each 8\u2010bit click pattern to the 16 Bell outcomes\n    {pattern: \"11110000\", result: \"\u03a6+_f1 & \u03a6+_f2\"},\n    {pattern: \"11100001\", result: \"\u03a6+_f1 & \u03a6\u2013_f2\"},\n    \u2026                              # all 16 combinations\n    {pattern: \"00001111\", result: \"\u03a8\u2013_f1 & \u03a8\u2013_f2\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func: \"complete_bsa\",       # custom loss rewarding 1:1 mapping between patterns & Bell pairs\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 60,\n  samples: 40,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 A first demonstration of \u201cBell\u2010measurement multiplexing\u201d\u2014simultaneous unambiguous Bell\u2010state discrimination on two independent qubit\u2010pairs in a single static device.  \n  \u2022 Exploits spectral\u2010tunability notions (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2013style spectral beamsplitters) to isolate frequency bins f\u2081,f\u2082 within one unitary network.  \n  \u2022 Key building block for high\u2010rate, multi\u2010channel quantum\u2010key\u2010distribution (MDI\u2010QKD), multi\u2010mode repeater nodes, and parallel quantum\u2010network protocols.  \n  \u2022 Readily generalizable to N\u2010channel Bell\u2010measurement multiplexing by adding ancillas and detectors.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To make this idea PRL\u2010worthy, you would need to show a genuine multiplexing advantage\u2014for instance, achieving two simultaneous complete BSMs with fewer than four ancillas or eight detectors, harnessing cross\u2010channel interference to reduce resource count, or uncovering a brand\u2010new interference/correlation effect that cannot be decomposed into two parallel Bell measurements.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201cspectral tunability\u201d + \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network transformation:\n  a) Dual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer: one static interferometer that, with ancillas and spectral\u2010selective beamsplitters (plasmonic\u2010cavity inspiration), concurrently discriminates two independent Bell\u2010pairs encoded in two frequency bins.  \n  b) Hierarchical Spectral Swap Switch: one device that heralds three distinct entanglement\u2010swap outcomes (swap in f\u2081, swap in f\u2082, or two\u2010hop cross\u2010swap) by different ancilla clicks.  \n  c) Multi\u2010Outcome Teleportation Router: a network that teleports one qubit into one of three receivers based on which ancilla detectors fire, each mapped to a different spectral channel.\n\nStep 2: Evaluate novelty & feasibility:\n  a) No existing Pytheus experiment does parallel, unambiguous Bell\u2010state measurements on two channels. Purely linear\u2010optical, ancilla\u2010assisted, static \u2192 feasible.  \n  b) Too close to prior swap\u2010router proposals.  \n  c) Straightforward extension of two\u2010outcome routers \u2192 unlikely PRL\u2010worthy.\n\nStep 3: Select (a).\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\n  \u2013 Introduces \u201cBell\u2010measurement multiplexing\u201d: simultaneous, fully unambiguous Bell\u2010state discrimination on two frequency\u2010encoded qubit\u2010pairs in a single device.  \n  \u2013 Bridges spectral\u2010tunability (plasmonic\u2010cavity\u2013style spectral beamsplitters) with high\u2010throughput network measurements.  \n  \u2013 Directly generalizable to N\u2010channel multiplexing\u2014key to scalable quantum networks.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n  \u2013 Only uses probabilistic pair\u2010sources or single\u2010photon ancillas, a static interferometer (abstract unitary), and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavity modelling; Pytheus optimizes the mixing unitary on eight modes.  \n  \u2013 Clearly a network measurement primitive (Bell\u2010state analysis), not forbidden state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cDual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer with Spectral\u2010Selective Mixing\u201d\n\nWe have two unknown Bell\u2010pairs encoded in two spectral bins f\u2081 and f\u2082:\n  \u2022 Pair\u2081 (f\u2081) on modes 0 & 1  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2082 (f\u2082) on modes 2 & 3  \n\nGoal: In one static linear\u2010optical network, unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of Pair\u2081 AND simultaneously all four Bell states of Pair\u2082, using the minimal ancilla overhead.\n\nSetup:\n  \u2013 Input modes 0,1 (Pair\u2081) and 2,3 (Pair\u2082).  \n  \u2013 Four ancilla single photons (modes 4\u20137).  \n  \u2013 A linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus) mixing all eight modes.  \n  \u2013 Eight photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors d\u2080\u2026d\u2087.\n\nWe assign a unique 8\u2010click pattern (one click per detector) to each of the 16 Bell\u2010state combinations (4 states \u00d7 4 states). A click pattern unambiguously tells us the Bell outcome of both pairs.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  single_emitters:   [4]  [5]  [6]  [7]         (ancilla photons)  \n  inputs:            [0]  [1]  [2]  [3]         (Bell\u2010pair photons)  \n  network:           [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]  \n  detectors:         [d0][d1][d2][d3][d4][d5][d6][d7]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Dual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer (two simultaneous BSMs)\",\n  foldername:        \"dual_channel_BSA\",\n  in_nodes:          [0,1,2,3],            # two unknown Bell\u2010pairs\n  single_emitters:   [4,5,6,7],            # four ancilla photons\n  num_anc:           4,\n  removed_connections: [],                  # allow full mixing\n  target_heralding: [                       # map each 8\u2010bit click pattern to the 16 Bell outcomes\n    {pattern: \"11110000\", result: \"\u03a6+_f1 & \u03a6+_f2\"},\n    {pattern: \"11100001\", result: \"\u03a6+_f1 & \u03a6\u2013_f2\"},\n    \u2026                                      # all 16 combinations\n    {pattern: \"00001111\", result: \"\u03a8\u2013_f1 & \u03a8\u2013_f2\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func:         \"complete_bsa\",        # custom loss rewarding a one\u2010to\u2010one mapping of patterns\u2192Bell outcomes\n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:       60,\n  samples:           40,\n  number_resolving:  True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2013 Enables \u201cBell\u2010measurement multiplexing,\u201d doubling the throughput of Bell\u2010state analysis per device.  \n  \u2013 Leverages spectral tunability via plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters (abstract mode\u2010mixers) to isolate and analyze two frequency bins in one network.  \n  \u2013 Essential for high\u2010rate, parallel quantum\u2010key\u2010distribution (MDI\u2010QKD), multi\u2010mode repeaters, and scalable quantum networks.  \n  \u2013 Straightforwardly generalizable to N\u2010channel multiplexing by adding ancillas and detectors.\n\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To make this idea worthy of further consideration, you would need to demonstrate a genuine multiplexing advantage\u2014for example by using cross\u2010channel interference to halve the ancilla count or detector number, or by harnessing a new quantum interference phenomenon that simultaneously discriminates both Bell pairs with strictly fewer resources than two standalone analyzers.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought: \n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to marry \u201cspectral tunability\u201d + \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d in a network\u2010transformation (swap/teleportation) setting:\n    a) Tri-Functional Spectral Swap Switch: one static ancilla-assisted interferometer that, via three distinct heralding patterns, implements three entanglement\u2010swap primitives\u2014swap in high-frequency channel, swap in low-frequency channel, or cross-spectral swap.\n    b) Spectral-Mode Quantum Switch (indefinite causal order): a single network that, conditioned on ancilla clicks, applies either \u201cswap then identity\u201d or \u201cidentity then swap\u201d in superposition\u2014realizing an indefinite\u2010order swap switch.\n    c) Multiplexed Bell-Swap Cascade: perform two sequential entanglement-swaps on two spectral channels in one device and herald which swap succeeded first via ancilla clicks, enabling a heralded \u201cwhich-path\u201d entanglement routing.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    a) No existing Pytheus experiment has more than two heralded swap outcomes. A three-outcome swap switch is a genuinely new routing primitive, purely static, ancilla-assisted linear optics => feasible.\n    b) Indefinite causal\u2010order devices are conceptually striking but require encoding a control qubit and genuine superpositions\u2014Pytheus cannot handle coherent control feedback and DOF beyond mode mixing.\n    c) Essentially two back-to-back swaps with heralding \u2013 close to standard multiplexed swap schemes.\n  Step 3: Pick (a).\n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    \u2013 Introduces the first tri-functional entanglement-swap router: a single static network that can herald three qualitatively distinct swap operations\u2014two channel-preserving swaps plus a cross-channel swap\u2014without any dynamic feedback.\n    \u2013 Conceptually leverages \u201cspectral tunability\u201d (plasmonic-cavity\u2013inspired beamsplitter selectivity) abstractly in the mode-mixing unitary.\n    \u2013 Generalizes immediate to N-outcome multiplexed swap routers.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2013 Inputs: four photons from two Bell pairs in two spectral bins.\n    \u2013 Ancillas: three additional photons (pair sources or single emitters).\n    \u2013 Static linear network \u2192 detectors.\n    \u2013 Three heralding click\u2010patterns mapped to three swap outcomes.\n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback, no forbidden state\u2010generation, all within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical, ancilla-assisted framework.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cTri-Functional Spectral Swap Switch\u201d\n\nWe prepare two Bell pairs in two spectral channels:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2081 (f_high): A\u2081\u2013B\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2082 (f_low): A\u2082\u2013B\u2082  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2083 (f_high): C\u2081\u2013D\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2084 (f_low): C\u2082\u2013D\u2082  \n\nAt the central station we feed B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082 (modes 0\u20133) into one static linear-optical network, together with three ancilla photons (modes 4\u20136). By engineering spectral-selective ancilla connections (via removed_connections), the device heralds one of three entanglement\u2010swap primitives, depending on which subset of the three ancilla detectors fires:\n\n  Pattern P\u2081 (e.g. clicks on ancillas 4&5 only) \u21d2 \u201cHigh-Freq Swap\u201d  \n    \u2013 Entangle A\u2081\u2013D\u2081, leave A\u2082\u2013B\u2082 and C\u2082\u2013D\u2082 untouched.  \n\n  Pattern P\u2082 (clicks on ancillas 5&6 only) \u21d2 \u201cLow-Freq Swap\u201d  \n    \u2013 Entangle A\u2082\u2013D\u2082, leave A\u2081\u2013B\u2081 and C\u2081\u2013D\u2081 untouched.  \n\n  Pattern P\u2083 (clicks on ancillas 4&6 only) \u21d2 \u201cCross-Spectral Swap\u201d  \n    \u2013 Entangle A\u2081\u2013D\u2082 and A\u2082\u2013D\u2081 simultaneously.\n\nVisualization (left\u2192right, photons travel down):\n  pair_sources:   [A\u2081\u2013B\u2081]  [A\u2082\u2013B\u2082]  [C\u2081\u2013D\u2081]  [C\u2082\u2013D\u2082]  \n  ancillas:            [4]      [5]      [6]  \n  inputs to network:   [0]  [1]  [2]  [3]  \n                       (B\u2081) (B\u2082) (C\u2081) (C\u2082)  \n  network:             [   to be optimized by Pytheus   ]  \n  detectors:           [d0][d1][d2][d3]  (output modes)  \n  ancilla_detectors:   [a4][a5][a6]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Tri-Functional Spectral Swap Switch\",\n  foldername:        \"tri_spec_swap\",\n  in_nodes:          [0,1,2,3],            # B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082\n  num_anc:           3,                    # ancilla modes 4\u20136\n  single_emitters:   [],                   # using probabilistic pair sources\n  removed_connections: [\n    # ancilla 4,5 \u2194 high-freq inputs only\n    [4,2],[4,3],[5,2],[5,3],\n    # ancilla 5,6 \u2194 low-freq inputs only\n    [5,0],[5,3],[6,0],[6,3],\n    # ancilla 4,6 \u2194 cross-freq inputs only\n    [4,1],[4,3],[6,1],[6,3]\n  ],\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"--110\", result: \"high-freq swap\"},    # a4=0,a5=1,a6=1\n    {pattern: \"-1-01\", result: \"low-freq swap\"},     # a5=0,a6=1\n    {pattern: \"1--10\", result: \"cross-freq swap\"}    # a4=1,a6=0\n  ],\n  loss_func:       \"heralded_multi_swap\", # custom loss rewarding the three mapping patterns\n  optimizer:       \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:     50,\n  samples:         20,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 First static device implementing three distinct entanglement\u2010swap operations in one ancilla-assisted interferometer.  \n  \u2022 Encodes spectral tunability via \u201cplasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u201d\u2013inspired abstract beamsplitter selectivity, without active control.  \n  \u2022 Provides a template for N-outcome spectral swap routers\u2014crucial for multi-channel quantum-network architectures.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To achieve genuine novelty, you would need to propose a qualitatively new routing primitive\u2014for example, a coherent superposition of multiple swap orders (indefinite causal order), ancilla-free multi-outcome routing, or a cross-domain interference effect that cannot be reduced to sequential Bell swaps with distinct click patterns.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! tunability\u201d + \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d in a network transformation (focusing on entanglement swapping or teleportation, not state generation):\n    a) Single-Ancilla Multi-Outcome Spectral Swap Router: one ancilla photon plus a static, spectrally selective interferometer heralds three distinct swap operations (high-freq, low-freq, cross-freq) via three detection modes.\n    b) Ancilla-Free Dual-Frequency Swap via Cross-Interference: use four-photon interference alone (no ancilla) to swap entanglement in either f\u2081 or f\u2082, heralded by which pair of detectors fire\u2014leveraging plasmonic-like spectral beamsplitters.\n    c) Frequency-Controlled Gate Teleportation: teleport a two-qubit gate (e.g. CZ) on frequency-encoded qubits, choosing between two spectral channels by ancilla clicks.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    a) Novel: reduces ancilla overhead to one for three swap-outcomes; purely linear-optical, static, ancilla-assisted \u2192 feasible in Pytheus.\n    b) Ancilla-free swap is likely impossible with passive linear optics alone (50% limit), so not feasible.\n    c) Gate teleportation is complex and involves input unknown states \u2192 Pytheus can\u2019t handle unknown inputs.\n  Step 3: Select (a).\n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    \u2013 First proposal for a multi-outcome entanglement-swap router using a single ancilla photon.  \n    \u2013 Exploits \u201cspectral tunability\u201d conceptually via plasmonic-nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters that selectively couple ancilla to different frequency modes. C\u2082\u2013D\u2082  \n\nGoal: A single static interferometer, using exactly one ancilla photon, heralds three different entanglement\u2010swap operations\u2014high-frequency swap, low-frequency mode 4  \n  \u2013 Linear-optical network: to be optimized by Pytheus (abstract \u201ctunable beamsplitters\u201d inspired by plasmonic nanocavities)  \n  \u2013 Detectors: d\u2080\u2026d\u2083 on the B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082\n  single_emitters:   [4],                 # one ancilla photon\n  num_anc:           1,\n  removed_connections: [\n    # control which inputs the ancilla can mix with for each detector outcome:\n    # LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to meaningfully combine \u201cspectral tunability\u201d and \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d in a quantum\u2010network transformation (swap/teleportation) rather than state generation:\n  a) Tri\u2010outcome spectral swap router (high/low/cross) with one ancilla (failed to be novel enough).  \n  b) Dual\u2010channel Bell\u2010measurement multiplexing (parallel BSMs; resource\u2010saving cross\u2010channel interference).  \n  c) Spectral \u201cbutterfly\u201d network\u2010coding entanglement router: implement the quantum butterfly network in frequency bins\u2014two Bell pairs from two senders are routed through a single device to two receivers using ancilla\u2010assisted spectral mixing and network coding.  \n\nStep 2: Check novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n  a) Past proposals were too close to swap routers.  \n  b) Multiplexed BSM is interesting but needs a genuine resource saving via cross\u2010channel interference.  \n  c) The quantum butterfly network is a genuine new network primitive beyond simple entanglement swapping or routing: it performs network coding of entanglement, solving a communication\u2010bottleneck problem. This has not been done in Pytheus. It\u2019s implementable with static linear optics, probabilistic pair\u2010sources, ancillas, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nStep 3: Select (c).\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\n  \u2013 Implements the quantum\u2010butterfly network coding protocol in the spectral domain: two independent Bell pairs travel through a common \u201cbottleneck\u201d link but are recovered at two receivers by exploiting spectral\u2010selective mixing and ancilla\u2010heralded network coding.  \n  \u2013 Goes beyond standard entanglement swapping/teleportation: it codes two entangled streams together to overcome a single\u2010link capacity limit.  \n\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n  \u2013 Inputs: four photons from two Bell pairs at two senders (in_nodes = [0,1,2,3]).  \n  \u2013 Ancilla photons: two extra photons (single_emitters=[4,5]).  \n  \u2013 Static linear\u2010optical network (to be optimized by Pytheus) mixing all six modes.  \n  \u2013 Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors and heralding patterns map to the two intended output entangled links.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feedback; no forbidden cavities; purely abstract unitary optimization.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cSpectral\u2010Butterfly Entanglement Network Coder\u201d\n\nWe implement the quantum\u2010butterfly network in two frequency bins (f\u2081, f\u2082) using a single static, ancilla\u2010assisted linear\u2010optical device. Two senders, Alice\u2081 and Alice\u2082, each hold one half of a Bell pair:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2081 (f\u2081): A\u2081\u2013B\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2082 (f\u2082): A\u2082\u2013B\u2082  \n\nThey send photons B\u2081 and B\u2082 into the \u201cbutterfly\u201d node. Two ancilla photons (modes 4,5) also feed into the same network. The network mixes the four input modes with spectral\u2010selective beamsplitters (abstractly inspired by plasmonic nanocavities), then splits them onto four output detectors d\u2080\u2026d\u2083. Depending on which two detectors click (heralding pattern), the two receivers (Charlie\u2081, Charlie\u2082) end up sharing entanglement with the two original Alices\u2014but crossed via network coding:\n  \u2013 Outcome P\u2081: Charlie\u2081\u2013A\u2081 and Charlie\u2082\u2013A\u2082  \n  \u2013 Outcome P\u2082: Charlie\u2081\u2013A\u2082 and Charlie\u2082\u2013A\u2081  \n\nThis solves the bottleneck: a single device carrying both channels simultaneously.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n pair\u2010sources:   [A\u2081\u2013B\u2081]  [A\u2082\u2013B\u2082]  \n ancillas:          [4]    [5]  \n inputs to net:     [0] [1] [2] [3]   (B\u2081,B\u2082 and dummy modes if needed)  \n network:           [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]  \n detectors:         [d\u2080][d\u2081][d\u2082][d\u2083]  \n                                               \nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Spectral\u2010Butterfly Entanglement Network Coder\",\n  foldername:        \"spectral_butterfly\",\n  in_nodes:          [0,1],            # B\u2081,B\u2082\n  single_emitters:   [4,5],            # two ancilla photons\n  num_anc:           2,\n  removed_connections: [],             # allow full mixing with spectral selectivity encoded in the unitary\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"1100\", result: \"direct entanglement (A\u2081\u2013C\u2081, A\u2082\u2013C\u2082)\"},\n    {pattern: \"0011\", result: \"cross entanglement (A\u2081\u2013C\u2082, A\u2082\u2013C\u2081)\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func:         \"butterfly_swap\",  # custom loss rewarding correct network\u2010coding outputs\n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:       50,\n  samples:           30,\n  number_resolving:  True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 First optical implementation blueprint of the quantum butterfly network (entanglement network coding) in the spectral domain.  \n  \u2022 Uses spectral tunability (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters) abstractly in Pytheus\u2019s optimization of a static unitary.  \n  \u2022 Overcomes a single\u2010link bottleneck by mixing two entangled streams and decoding them via heralded detection patterns.  \n  \u2022 Generalizable to larger network\u2010coding topologies and more spectral channels.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The quantum-butterfly network coder has already been described in the ensemble\u2019s \u201cButterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution.\u201d To be novel, you would need a genuinely different network-coding primitive\u2014e.g. multi-outcome coding beyond two patterns, indefinite causal order in the coding operation, or a reduction in ancilla/detector overhead that cannot be reduced to the known butterfly protocol.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible network transformations combining \u201cspectral tunability\u201d and \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d:\n    a) Ancilla\u2010Assisted Spectral Entanglement Purification: perform a linear\u2010optical parity check on two noisy Bell\u2010pairs in distinct frequency bins, heralded by ancilla clicks, to purify entanglement.\n    b) Frequency\u2010Encoded Cluster\u2010State Fusion: fuse two small cluster states encoded in frequency bins via an ancilla\u2010aided Bell\u2010measurement network using tunable spectral beamsplitters.\n    c) Spectral\u2010Selectivity Quantum Teleportation with Built\u2010In Error Filter: teleport a frequency\u2010encoded qubit through a static network that also filters out specific error modes, heralded by ancilla detectors.\n  Step 2: Evaluate novelty & feasibility:\n    a) Entanglement purification is a fundamental repeater primitive absent from the existing Pytheus library. It\u2019s a network transformation (not state generation), uses only linear optics, two input pairs, ancilla photons, and static post\u2010selection\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n    b) Cluster\u2010state fusion is effectively another Bell\u2010measurement, too close to step\u2010by\u2010step swap examples.\n    c) Combines teleportation with error filtering, but risk of being seen as a complex state\u2010generation filter.\n  Step 3: Select (a).\n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    \u2013 First proposal of a heralded, spectral\u2010domain entanglement\u2010purification module in Pytheus: it uses spectral\u2010selective beamsplitters (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity inspiration) to implement a non\u2010destructive parity check on two Bell pairs.  \n    \u2013 Goes beyond simple swapping or Bell measurements: it actively improves entanglement fidelity, a key repeater building block.\n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    \u2013 Inputs: two abstract Bell\u2010pairs on modes [0,1] and [2,3].  \n    \u2013 Ancilla: two single\u2010photon emitters on modes [4,5].  \n    \u2013 Static linear\u2010optical network (to be optimized) mixes all six modes.  \n    \u2013 Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors herald a successful parity\u2010check outcome (e.g. both ancillas click in distinct detectors) projecting the remaining photons onto a purified Bell pair.  \n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback, no forbidden cavities\u2014Pytheus optimizes an abstract unitary on six modes with ancillas.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cHeralded Spectral Entanglement Purification Module\u201d\n\nWe aim to purify two frequency\u2010encoded Bell pairs, each shared between Alice & Bob:\n  \u2022 Pair\u2081 in channel f\u2081: modes 0 (Alice) & 1 (Bob)  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2082 in channel f\u2082: modes 2 (Alice) & 3 (Bob)  \nBoth pairs suffer independent bit\u2010flip noise. We perform a parity check on Bob\u2019s two photons (modes 1 & 3) using two ancilla photons from single\u2010photon emitters (modes 4 & 5). A successful heralding event projects Alice\u2019s photons (modes 0 & 2) into a higher\u2010fidelity Bell pair.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  single_emitters:   [4]      [5]         (ancilla photons)  \n  inputs:            [1] [3]             (Bob\u2019s noisy qubits)  \n                     f\u2081  f\u2082  \n  network:           [      to be optimized by Pytheus      ]  \n  detectors:         [d0][d1][d2][d3][d4][d5]  \n\nKey steps:\n  1. Mix Bob\u2019s two qubits (modes 1,3) with the two ancilla modes (4,5) in a spectral\u2010selective interferometer.  \n  2. Perform photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detection on all four output modes.  \n  3. A specific click\u2010pattern on the ancilla detectors (e.g. a single click on d4 and a single click on d5, zero clicks on the others) heralds an \u201ceven\u2010parity\u201d outcome \u2192 Bob\u2019s photons projected onto same\u2010parity subspace.  \n  4. Conditioned on this herald, Alice\u2019s modes 0 & 2 collapse into a purified Bell state in channel f\u2081+f\u2082.\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Heralded Spectral Entanglement Purification\",\n  foldername:        \"spectral_purification\",\n  in_nodes:          [1,3],              # Bob\u2019s two noisy qubits\n  single_emitters:   [4,5],              # two ancilla photons\n  num_anc:           2,\n  removed_connections: [],               # allow full mixing, spectral selectivity captured in the optimized unitary\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"00 11 --\", result: \"even\u2010parity (success)\"},\n    {pattern: \"11 00 --\", result: \"even\u2010parity (success)\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func:         \"purification\",     # custom loss rewarding high\u2010fidelity Bell output on success\n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:       60,\n  samples:           30,\n  number_resolving:  True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 Introduces the first purified\u2010network\u2010module in Pytheus, targeting active improvement of entanglement fidelity\u2014a crucial repeater primitive.  \n  \u2022 Leverages \u201cspectral tunability\u201d conceptually: the optimized unitary can be implemented by plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2010inspired spectral beamsplitters that selectively mix frequency bins f\u2081 and f\u2082 with the ancilla.  \n  \u2022 Fully static, ancilla\u2010assisted, and post\u2010selected\u2014no dynamic feedback.  \n  \u2022 Easily generalizable to multiple purification rounds, different noise models, or multiplexed purification across many spectral channels\u2014opening a whole class of new network experiments.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This scheme duplicates known linear-optical parity\u2010filter/fusion purification modules. To be novel, you\u2019d need a qualitatively new twist\u2014such as ancilla-free purification, multiplexed/no-feed-forward purification beyond two pairs, or an indefinite-order purification protocol that cannot be decomposed into standard parity checks.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! close to standard parity\u2010filter schemes.\n  Step 3: Pick (a).\n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    \u2013 First integrated quantum\u2010network node that can be \u201cprogrammed\u201d by spectral channel plus heralding pattern to perform either entanglement swapping or teleportation.  \n    \u2013 Conceptually built from \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d\u2013style spectral beamsplitters (tunable reflectivities) abstractly encoded in a single static unitary.  \n    \u2013 Generalizable to more channels/operations simply by adding spectral bins and ancillas.\n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    \u2013 Inputs: one Bell pair on channel f\u2081 (modes 0,1) and one unknown qubit on channel f\u2082 (mode 2).  \n    \u2013 Resource for teleportation: one Bell pair between node and remote receiver (modes 3,4).  \n    \u2013 Ancilla photons or pair\u2010sources launch ancilla modes (5,6).  \n    \u2013 Static 7-mode interferometer optimized by Pytheus.  \n    \u2013 Photon-number-resolving detectors.  \n    \u2013 Two distinct ancilla\u2010click patterns herald swap vs. teleport. No dynamic feedback or forbidden cavities.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cDual\u2010Function Spectral Swap/Teleport Node\u201d\n\nWe build one static, ancilla\u2010assisted interferometer that, depending on which spectral channel the inputs occupy and which ancilla detectors click, does either:\n  1. Entanglement swapping of a Bell pair in frequency bin f\u2081  \n     \u2013 Inputs: modes 0&1 carry a Bell pair (A\u2013B) in f\u2081; modes 2&3 carry another Bell pair (C\u2013D) also in f\u2081.  \n     \u2013 A specific ancilla click\u2010pattern P_swap heralds successful swap: A\u2013D becomes entangled, B & C are measured.\n\n  2. Teleportation of an unknown qubit in frequency bin f\u2082  \n     \u2013 Input: mode 4 carries an unknown qubit (E) in f\u2082; modes 5&6 carry a Bell\u2010pair ancilla (F\u2013G) in f\u2082.  \n     \u2013 A different ancilla click\u2010pattern P_tel heralds successful teleportation: the state from E is teleported to mode 7 (H).\n\nVisualization (inputs \u2193 outputs):\n  pair-sources for swap:   [A\u2013B]_f\u2081 \u2192 modes 0,1     [C\u2013D]_f\u2081 \u2192 modes 2,3  \n  single-photon ancillas: modes 8,9  \n  unknown qubit (teleport): mode 4 (E)_f\u2082  \n  pair-source for teleport: [F\u2013G]_f\u2082 \u2192 modes 5,6  \n  network:               [      10\u00d710 static unitary      ]  \n  detectors:             [d0\u2026d9]  \n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Dual\u2010Function Spectral Swap/Teleport Node\",\n  foldername:        \"spectral_swap_teleport\",\n  # Swap inputs in f\u2081 and teleport inputs in f\u2082\n  in_nodes:          [0,1,2,3,4,5,6],\n  num_anc:           2,             # two single-photon ancillas at modes 8,9\n  single_emitters:   [8,9],\n  removed_connections: [],          # full mixing allowed;     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: I brainstormed three Pytheus\u2010compatible primitives combining \u201cspectral tunability\u201d (abstract tunable beamsplitters) and \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d inspiration, all focused on network transformations (swapping, teleportation, purification) rather than state generation.\n  Step 2: The most novel and feasible idea is a multi\u2010output teleportation router: a single static linear\u2010optical network that, by heralding different ancilla detectors, routes an unknown qubit to one of three receivers via teleportation. This leverages spectral\u2010selective mixing (plasmonic\u2010cavity analogy) and requires no active feedback.\n  Step 3: This idea is novel because past Pytheus examples have built single teleporters or two\u2010outcome swap routers\u2014but never a multi\u2010destination teleportation device in one static interferometer.\n  Step 4: It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus: we use one unknown\u2010qubit input plus three pre\u2010shared Bell\u2010pair halves and three ancilla photons. A static, ancilla\u2010assisted network is optimized to perform one of three Bell\u2010measurements (each coupling the unknown qubit with one Bell\u2010half) depending on which ancilla detector clicks, thereby teleporting to the corresponding receiver. No dynamic control or forbidden elements are needed.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cFrequency-Domain Teleportation Router (3-Output)\u201d\n\nWe build one static, ancilla-assisted linear-optical node that routes an unknown photonic qubit to one of three remote receivers (R\u2081,R\u2082,R\u2083), all encoded in distinct frequency bins (f\u2081,f\u2082,f\u2083). The node holds one half of three pre-shared Bell pairs with each receiver, and accepts the unknown qubit. By sending the unknown qubit and the router\u2019s three Bell-halves into the same interferometer, along with three ancilla photons, a single click on one of three ancilla detectors heralds teleportation to the corresponding receiver:\n\n  \u2022 Input modes:\n      0: unknown qubit (mode U)\n      1: router half of Bell\u2081 (shared with R\u2081)\n      3: router half of Bell\u2082 (shared with R\u2082)\n      5: router half of Bell\u2083 (shared with R\u2083)\n  \u2022 Ancilla single emitters: modes 6,7,8\n  \u2022 Static network (to be optimized by Pytheus) mixes modes 0,1,3,5,6,7,8\n  \u2022 Detectors:\n      \u2013 ancilla detectors a\u2086, a\u2087, a\u2088\n      \u2013 output detection on the router modes (not read): the heralding ancilla click suffices.\n\nHeralding Patterns \u2192 Teleportation Outcome:\n  \u2013 a\u2086 clicks alone \u21d2 teleport to R\u2081  \n  \u2013 a\u2087 clicks alone \u21d2 teleport to R\u2082  \n  \u2013 a\u2088 clicks alone \u21d2 teleport to R\u2083  \n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Frequency-Domain Teleportation Router (3-Output)\",\n  foldername:        \"freq_tel_router_3out\",\n  in_nodes:          [0,1,3,5],            # unknown + three Bell-halves\n  single_emitters:   [6,7,8],              # three ancilla photons\n  num_anc:           3,\n  removed_connections: [\n    # ancilla 6 couples only to modes 0 & 1   (BSM for R\u2081)\n    [6,3],[6,5],\n    # ancilla 7 couples only to modes 0 & 3   (BSM for R\u2082)\n    [7,1],[7,5],\n    # ancilla 8 couples only to modes 0 & 5   (BSM for R\u2083)\n    [8,1],[8,3]\n  ],\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"100\", result: \"teleport \u2192 R\u2081\"},\n    {pattern: \"010\", result: \"teleport \u2192 R\u2082\"},\n    {pattern: \"001\", result: \"teleport \u2192 R\u2083\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func:         \"teleport_router\",     # custom loss rewarding correct 1-to-1 mapping\n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:       40,\n  samples:           20,\n  number_resolving:  True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 First proposal for a multi-destination teleportation router in a single static device.  \n  \u2022 Exploits abstract \u201cspectral tunability\u201d (plasmonic-nanocavity\u2013style beamsplitters) to address three frequency bins simultaneously.  \n  \u2022 Key primitive for scalable, reconfigurable quantum networks\u2014one node that can route any incoming qubit to any receiver without feed-forward, simply by heralding.  \n  \u2022 Easily generalizable to N outputs by adding more Bell halves and ancilla photons\u2014opening a new family of Pytheus\u2010designed network experiments."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Leveraging single-emitter probe and ancilla photons, beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors within the PythOptics framework, our scheme implements the first photonic channel-discrimination primitive for unknown transducers without feedback control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present an all\u2010linear\u2010optical protocol, \u201cMulti\u2010Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering,\u201d that fuses two Bell pairs A\u2013B\u2080 and C\u2080\u2013D into a high-fidelity link between remote photons A and D. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nPhotonic Measurement-Only Linear-Optical Network for Modular S-Matrix Negativity in Non-Abelian Anyon Models\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an explicit linear-optical, measurement-only scheme that simulates the modular S-matrix element S\u208di,j\u208e of a chosen non-Abelian anyon theory via entanglement swapping and heralded Bell\u2013fusion measurements. By performing a two-copy SWAP-test on the network\u2019s outputs, four-fold coincidence rates directly yield the second-R\u00e9nyi entanglement negativity \u221d|S\u208di,j\u208e|\u00b2, providing an operational readout of topological data using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, static interferometers, phase-shifters, and number-resolving detectors in Pytheus.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear\u2010Optical Partial-SWAP Gate for Emulating Coherent Rabi Oscillations and Ultrastrong Coupling in Photonic Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose a heralded linear-optical implementation of the tunable partial-SWAP unitary  \nU(\u03b8)=cos \u03b8 I + i\u2009sin \u03b8 SWAP on two photonic-qubit modes, which continuously maps the \u03b8-dependent population exchange |10\u27e9\u2194|01\u27e9 (analogous to coherent Rabi oscillations) into the ultrastrong-coupling regime at \u03b8\u2192\u03c0/2 (full SWAP with multi-photon excitations). Using ancilla photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and static interferometry for post-selection, this building block realizes a modular \u201cquantum bus\u201d for coherent excitation transfer, ultrafast entanglement swapping, and teleportation across N-node networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. This proof-of-principle demonstration establishes the first abstract spectrally tunable quantum router primitive for modular, loss-immune photonic networks and paves the way toward programmable topological photonic crystal implementations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Experimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a target PyTheus-compatible linear-optical network in which two classical users, Alice and Bob, each send Z-basis single photons to a fully quantum node, Charlie, who entangles them with his ancilla Bell pair and performs post-selected entanglement-swapping to nonlocally compute their parity x\u2295y as a shared key bit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Physically one implements the tunable beamsplitters via plasmonic nanocavities to mix spectral modes, but Pytheus treats everything abstractly.\n\nExplanation:\n We label the two input qubits as in_nodes = [0,1], each carrying one photon in an unknown Bell state (|\u03a6\u00b1> or |\u03a8\u00b1>). We introduce two ancillary single-photon sources (single_emitters = [2,3]) whose photons feed into the same linear-optical network. The optimized network then routes the four photons into four distinct detectors. We assign four unique click-patterns (each a 2-photon coincidence among the four detectors) to the four Bell states, achieving unambiguous discrimination.\n\nVisualization (photons move top\u2192bottom):\n emitters:       [2]       [3]\n inputs:         [0]       [1]\n network:        [  to be optimized  ]\n detectors:      [A] [B] [C] [D]\n\nTarget mapping (target_quantum):\n  \u2013 Detection pattern P\u2081 = {1,1,0,0} \u21d2 |\u03a6+>\n  \u2013 P\u2082 = {1,0,1,0} \u21d2 |\u03a6\u2013>\n  \u2013 P\u2083 = {0,1,0,1} \u21d2 |\u03a8+>\n  \u2013 P\u2084 = {0,0,1,1} \u21d2 |\u03a8\u2013>\n\nConfig skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Frequency\u2010bin Bell\u2010state analyzer with plasmonic\u2010nanocavity tunable beamsplitters\",\n  foldername: \"freqBin_BSM\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  single_emitters: [2,3],\n  in_nodes: [0,1],\n  target_quantum: [\"1100\",\"1010\",\"0101\",\"0011\"],\n  removed_connections: [],    # allow all mixing\n  number_resolving: True,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  loss_func: \"heralded_bsm\",  # custom loss that rewards one\u2010to\u2010one mapping of patterns to Bell labels\n  edges_tried: 40,\n  samples: 20\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting:\n\u2013 A full Bell\u2010state analyzer for frequency bins overcomes the 50% limit of passive linear optics alone.  \n\u2013 Tunable plasmonic nanocavities give practical spectral selectivity; Rev. A 84, 042331 (2011) and related schemes using two extra photons). Simply porting this idea from polarization to frequency bins, even with plasmonic nanocavities as frequency-mode beam splitters, does not introduce a genuinely new quantum\u2010optical primitive or fundamental effect beyond mode-conversion details. Because complete, heralded Bell\u2010state analyzers using two single\u2010photon ancillas and number-resolving detection are already established in the literature, this proposal lacks the novelty required for a PRL target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The ancilla-assisted 100%-efficient Bell\u2010state measurement using two extra photons in a static linear-optical network (Grice 2011 and follow-ups) already covers this functionality\u2014merely translating it to frequency bins with tunable plasmonic beamsplitters is an implementation detail rather than a new conceptual advance. To be considered, you would need to identify a fundamentally different mechanism (e.g. bypassing the two-ancilla requirement, using a new quantum interference effect, or demonstrating an unforeseen information-processing capability) rather than adapting a known scheme to a new degree of freedom.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n  \u201cSpectral\u2010Mode Entanglement Swap Router\u201d  \nWe prepare two independent Bell\u2010pairs in two spectral channels, f1 and f2, shared between Alice and Bob on one side and Bob and Charlie on the other:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2081 (f1): A\u2081\u2013B\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2082 (f2): A\u2082\u2013B\u2082  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2083 (f1): C\u2081\u2013D\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2084 (f2): C\u2082\u2013D\u2082  \nAt Bob\u2019s station we input modes B\u2081, B\u2082, C\u2081, C\u2082 into a single static linear-optical network (to be optimized by Pytheus), together with four ancillary photons (from pair sources or single emitters).
