custom loss rewarding correct multi-outcome swaps\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  samples: 20,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n \u2013 First \u201cquantum repeater switch\u201d that conditionally performs different numbers of entanglement-swap hops and selectively operates in multiple spectral channels\u2014in one static device.  \n \u2013 Captures the spirit of spectral tunability (plasmonic-nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters) in an abstract, feedback-free linear-optical network.  \n \u2013 Opens a new route to hierarchical, spectrally-multiplexed quantum-network primitives and can be generalized to more channels or hops.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The \u201cSpectral-Multiplexed Hierarchical Entanglement Switch\u201d is just a straightforward extension of the same ancilla-heralded, static linear-optical entanglement-swap router/switch concept you\u2019ve already proposed (and which closely parallels ensemble ideas like the \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router\u201d and the \u201cMultiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\u201d). Merely adding a third click pattern for a two-hop swap in another frequency channel does not introduce a new interference mechanism, resource efficiency, or fundamental network capability beyond trivial multi-outcome relabeling. This fails to meet the bar for a genuinely novel PRL-worthy quantum-optical primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To reach novelty, you\u2019d need to propose a qualitatively new routing primitive\u2014such as a coherent superposition of multiple swap orders, ancilla-free multi-outcome routing, or a nonclassical interference effect that cannot be reduced to sequential Bell swaps with distinct heralding clicks.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n  \u201cDual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer with Spectral\u2010Selective Mixing\u201d  \n\nWe have two unknown Bell\u2010pairs encoded in two frequency bins f\u2081 and f\u2082:\n  \u2022 Pair\u2081 (f\u2081) on modes 0 & 1  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2082 (f\u2082) on modes 2 & 3  \n\nGoal: In one static interferometer, unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of Pair\u2081 AND simultaneously all four Bell states of Pair\u2082, using a minimal number of ancilla photons.\n\nSetup:\n  \u2013 Input qubits: modes 0,1 and modes 2,3  \n  \u2013 Ancilla photons: from four single\u2010photon emitters (modes 4\u20137)  \n  \u2013 Linear\u2010optical network: to be optimized by Pytheus, mixes all eight modes  \n  \u2013 8 photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors: d\u2080\u2026d\u2087  \n\nWe assign a unique 8\u2010click pattern (one click per detector) to each of the 16 possible Bell\u2010state combinations (4 states \u00d7 4 states). Successful heralding of a particular pattern tells us both the Bell outcome for Pair\u2081 and for Pair\u2082.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  single_emitters:   [4]  [5]  [6]  [7]         (ancilla photons)  \n  inputs:            [0]  [1]  [2]  [3]         (Bell\u2010pair photons)  \n  network:           [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]  \n  detectors:         [d0][d1][d2][d3][d4][d5][d6][d7]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Dual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer (two simultaneous BSMs)\",\n  foldername: \"dual_channel_BSA\",\n  in_nodes: [0,1,2,3],            # the two unknown Bell\u2010pairs\n  single_emitters: [4,5,6,7],     # four ancilla photons\n  num_anc: 4,\n  removed_connections: [],        # allow full mixing\n  target_heralding: [             # map each 8\u2010bit click pattern to the 16 Bell outcomes\n    {pattern: \"11110000\", result: \"\u03a6+_f1 & \u03a6+_f2\"},\n    {pattern: \"11100001\", result: \"\u03a6+_f1 & \u03a6\u2013_f2\"},\n    \u2026                              # all 16 combinations\n    {pattern: \"00001111\", result: \"\u03a8\u2013_f1 & \u03a8\u2013_f2\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func: \"complete_bsa\",       # custom loss rewarding 1:1 mapping between patterns & Bell pairs\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 60,\n  samples: 40,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 A first demonstration of \u201cBell\u2010measurement multiplexing\u201d\u2014simultaneous unambiguous Bell\u2010state discrimination on two independent qubit\u2010pairs in a single static device.  \n  \u2022 Exploits spectral\u2010tunability notions (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2013style spectral beamsplitters) to isolate frequency bins f\u2081,f\u2082 within one unitary network.  \n  \u2022 Key building block for high\u2010rate, multi\u2010channel quantum\u2010key\u2010distribution (MDI\u2010QKD), multi\u2010mode repeater nodes, and parallel quantum\u2010network protocols.  \n  \u2022 Readily generalizable to N\u2010channel Bell\u2010measurement multiplexing by adding ancillas and detectors.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While multiplexed Bell-state discrimination across two frequency channels is operationally useful, this proposal merely scales the well-known ancilla-assisted complete Bell\u2010state analyzer (e.g. Grice PRA 84, 042331 (2011)) from one qubit pair to two, without reducing ancilla or detector resources or introducing a novel interference mechanism. It simply duplicates the two\u2010ancilla, four\u2010detector scheme for each channel within one larger interferometer, lacking any fundamental new primitive or resource advantage.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To make this idea PRL\u2010worthy, you would need to show a genuine multiplexing advantage\u2014for instance, achieving two simultaneous complete BSMs with fewer than four ancillas or eight detectors, harnessing cross\u2010channel interference to reduce resource count, or uncovering a brand\u2010new interference/correlation effect that cannot be decomposed into two parallel Bell measurements.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n  \u201cDual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer with Spectral\u2010Selective Mixing\u201d\n\nWe have two unknown Bell\u2010pairs encoded in two spectral bins f\u2081 and f\u2082:\n  \u2022 Pair\u2081 (f\u2081) on modes 0 & 1  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2082 (f\u2082) on modes 2 & 3  \n\nGoal: In one static linear\u2010optical network, unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of Pair\u2081 AND simultaneously all four Bell states of Pair\u2082, using the minimal ancilla overhead.\n\nSetup:\n  \u2013 Input modes 0,1 (Pair\u2081) and 2,3 (Pair\u2082).  \n  \u2013 Four ancilla single photons (modes 4\u20137).  \n  \u2013 A linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus) mixing all eight modes.  \n  \u2013 Eight photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors d\u2080\u2026d\u2087.\n\nWe assign a unique 8\u2010click pattern (one click per detector) to each of the 16 Bell\u2010state combinations (4 states \u00d7 4 states). It simply duplicates the well\u2010known 2\u2010ancilla, 4\u2010detector linear\u2010optical BSM (Grice 2011\u2010style) for each band within a single 8\u2010mode interferometer. That trivial scaling offers no conceptual advance, resource saving, or unexpected quantum effect, so it fails to meet the bar for a PRL\u2010worthy novelty.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To make this idea worthy of further consideration, you would need to demonstrate a genuine multiplexing advantage\u2014for example by using cross\u2010channel interference to halve the ancilla count or detector number, or by harnessing a new quantum interference phenomenon that simultaneously discriminates both Bell pairs with strictly fewer resources than two standalone analyzers.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n  \u201cTri-Functional Spectral Swap Switch\u201d\n\nWe prepare two Bell pairs in two spectral channels:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2081 (f_high): A\u2081\u2013B\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2082 (f_low): A\u2082\u2013B\u2082  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2083 (f_high): C\u2081\u2013D\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2084 (f_low): C\u2082\u2013D\u2082  \n\nAt the central station we feed B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082 (modes 0\u20133) into one static linear-optical network, together with three ancilla photons (modes 4\u20136). By engineering spectral-selective ancilla connections (via removed_connections), the device heralds one of three entanglement\u2010swap primitives, depending on which subset of the three ancilla detectors fires:\n\n  Pattern P\u2081 (e.g. clicks on ancillas 4&5 only) \u21d2 \u201cHigh-Freq Swap\u201d  \n    \u2013 Entangle A\u2081\u2013D\u2081, leave A\u2082\u2013B\u2082 and C\u2082\u2013D\u2082 untouched.  \n\n  Pattern P\u2082 (clicks on ancillas 5&6 only) \u21d2 \u201cLow-Freq Swap\u201d  \n    \u2013 Entangle A\u2082\u2013D\u2082, leave A\u2081\u2013B\u2081 and C\u2081\u2013D\u2081 untouched.  \n\n  Pattern P\u2083 (clicks on ancillas 4&6 only) \u21d2 \u201cCross-Spectral Swap\u201d  \n    \u2013 Entangle A\u2081\u2013D\u2082 and A\u2082\u2013D\u2081 simultaneously.\n\nVisualization (left\u2192right, photons travel down):\n  pair_sources:   [A\u2081\u2013B\u2081]  [A\u2082\u2013B\u2082]  [C\u2081\u2013D\u2081]  [C\u2082\u2013D\u2082]  \n  ancillas:            [4]      [5]      [6]  \n  inputs to network:   [0]  [1]  [2]  [3]  \n                       (B\u2081) (B\u2082) (C\u2081) (C\u2082)  \n  network:             [   to be optimized by Pytheus   ]  \n  detectors:           [d0][d1][d2][d3]  (output modes)  \n  ancilla_detectors:   [a4][a5][a6]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Tri-Functional Spectral Swap Switch\",\n  foldername:        \"tri_spec_swap\",\n  in_nodes:          [0,1,2,3],            # B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082\n  num_anc:           3,                    # ancilla modes 4\u20136\n  single_emitters:   [],                   # using probabilistic pair sources\n  removed_connections: [\n    # ancilla 4,5 \u2194 high-freq inputs only\n    [4,2],[4,3],[5,2],[5,3],\n    # ancilla 5,6 \u2194 low-freq inputs only\n    [5,0],[5,3],[6,0],[6,3],\n    # ancilla 4,6 \u2194 cross-freq inputs only\n    [4,1],[4,3],[6,1],[6,3]\n  ],\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"--110\", result: \"high-freq swap\"},    # a4=0,a5=1,a6=1\n    {pattern: \"-1-01\", result: \"low-freq swap\"},     # a5=0,a6=1\n    {pattern: \"1--10\", result: \"cross-freq swap\"}    # a4=1,a6=0\n  ],\n  loss_func:       \"heralded_multi_swap\", # custom loss rewarding the three mapping patterns\n  optimizer:       \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:     50,\n  samples:         20,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 First static device implementing three distinct entanglement\u2010swap operations in one ancilla-assisted interferometer.  \n  \u2022 Encodes spectral tunability via \u201cplasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u201d\u2013inspired abstract beamsplitter selectivity, without active control.  \n  \u2022 Provides a template for N-outcome spectral swap routers\u2014crucial for multi-channel quantum-network architectures.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed tri\u2010functional spectral swap switch is essentially a straightforward extension of the same ancilla-heralded, static linear-optical entanglement router/switch concepts already explored (including your earlier spectral routers and ensemble proposals). Simply adding a third heralding pattern to choose among high-freq, low-freq, or cross-freq swaps doesn\u2019t introduce a new interference mechanism, resource saving, or network capability beyond trivial multi-outcome relabeling. a4 clicks\n    {pattern: \"-----1-\", result: \"low-freq swap\"},    # a5 clicks\n    {pattern: \"------1\", result: \"cross-freq swap\"}   # a6 clicks\n  ],\n  loss_func:         \"heralded_swap_multi\", # custom loss rewarding the three correct mappings\n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:       40,\n  samples:           25,\n  number_resolving:  True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 Achieves three heralded swap operations in one static device using only one ancilla photon\u2014a resource saving over one-ancilla-per-outcome schemes.  \n  \u2022 Conceptually employs \u201cspectral tunability\u201d via plasmonic-nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters that selectively couple ancilla to different frequency modes.  \n  \u2022 Introduces a new quantum-network primitive\u2014multi-outcome entanglement-swap routing with minimal ancilla overhead\u2014extensible to more channels and outcomes.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is just a minor resource\u2010trade variant of the standard ancilla\u2010heralded entanglement\u2013swap router: you\u2019ve simply consolidated three click\u2010patterns into one ancilla photon with multiple output ports. There\u2019s no new interference principle (indefinite order, coherent superposition of swap paths, or cross\u2010modal entanglement) and no genuine reduction in overall ancilla-plus-detector resources beyond trivial rerouting of the same ancilla. It remains a static ancilla-driven multi-outcome Bell-swap, a concept already explored in both ensemble and literature proposals.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To reach PRL\u2010level novelty you would need a qualitatively new routing primitive\u2014e.g. a coherent superposition of multiple swap orders, an ancilla-free multi-outcome operation, or an interference mechanism that cannot be reduced to conventional Bell-swap heralding with mere mode relabeling.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n  \u201cSpectral\u2010Butterfly Entanglement Network Coder\u201d\n\nWe implement the quantum\u2010butterfly network in two frequency bins (f\u2081, f\u2082) using a single static, ancilla\u2010assisted linear\u2010optical device. Two senders, Alice\u2081 and Alice\u2082, each hold one half of a Bell pair:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2081 (f\u2081): A\u2081\u2013B\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2082 (f\u2082): A\u2082\u2013B\u2082  \n\nThey send photons B\u2081 and B\u2082 into the \u201cbutterfly\u201d node. Two ancilla photons (modes 4,5) also feed into the same network. The network mixes the four input modes with spectral\u2010selective beamsplitters (abstractly inspired by plasmonic nanocavities), then splits them onto four output detectors d\u2080\u2026d\u2083. Depending on which two detectors click (heralding pattern), the two receivers (Charlie\u2081, Charlie\u2082) end up sharing entanglement with the two original Alices\u2014but crossed via network coding:\n  \u2013 Outcome P\u2081: Charlie\u2081\u2013A\u2081 and Charlie\u2082\u2013A\u2082  \n  \u2013 Outcome P\u2082: Charlie\u2081\u2013A\u2082 and Charlie\u2082\u2013A\u2081  \n\nThis solves the bottleneck: a single device carrying both channels simultaneously.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n pair\u2010sources:   [A\u2081\u2013B\u2081]  [A\u2082\u2013B\u2082]  \n ancillas:          [4]    [5]  \n inputs to net:     [0] [1] [2] [3]   (B\u2081,B\u2082 and dummy modes if needed)  \n network:           [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]  \n detectors:         [d\u2080][d\u2081][d\u2082][d\u2083]  \n                                               \nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Spectral\u2010Butterfly Entanglement Network Coder\",\n  foldername:        \"spectral_butterfly\",\n  in_nodes:          [0,1],            # B\u2081,B\u2082\n  single_emitters:   [4,5],            # two ancilla photons\n  num_anc:           2,\n  removed_connections: [],             # allow full mixing with spectral selectivity encoded in the unitary\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"1100\", result: \"direct entanglement (A\u2081\u2013C\u2081, A\u2082\u2013C\u2082)\"},\n    {pattern: \"0011\", result: \"cross entanglement (A\u2081\u2013C\u2082, A\u2082\u2013C\u2081)\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func:         \"butterfly_swap\",  # custom loss rewarding correct network\u2010coding outputs\n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:       50,\n  samples:           30,\n  number_resolving:  True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 First optical implementation blueprint of the quantum butterfly network (entanglement network coding) in the spectral domain.  \n  \u2022 Uses spectral tunability (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters) abstractly in Pytheus\u2019s optimization of a static unitary.  \n  \u2022 Overcomes a single\u2010link bottleneck by mixing two entangled streams and decoding them via heralded detection patterns.  \n  \u2022 Generalizable to larger network\u2010coding topologies and more spectral channels.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially identical to the previously suggested \u201cButterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution,\u201d which already realizes entanglement network coding (butterfly) in a static linear-optical device with heralded outcomes. There is no new interference mechanism, resource saving, or conceptual advance beyond relabeling spectral bins.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The quantum-butterfly network coder has already been described in the ensemble\u2019s \u201cButterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution.\u201d To be novel, you would need a genuinely different network-coding primitive\u2014e.g. multi-outcome coding beyond two patterns, indefinite causal order in the coding operation, or a reduction in ancilla/detector overhead that cannot be reduced to the known butterfly protocol.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n  \u201cHeralded Spectral Entanglement Purification Module\u201d\n\nWe aim to purify two frequency\u2010encoded Bell pairs, each shared between Alice & Bob:\n  \u2022 Pair\u2081 in channel f\u2081: modes 0 (Alice) & 1 (Bob)  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2082 in channel f\u2082: modes 2 (Alice) & 3 (Bob)  \nBoth pairs suffer independent bit\u2010flip noise. We perform a parity check on Bob\u2019s two photons (modes 1 & 3) using two ancilla photons from single\u2010photon emitters (modes 4 & 5). A successful heralding event projects Alice\u2019s photons (modes 0 & 2) into a higher\u2010fidelity Bell pair.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  single_emitters:   [4]      [5]         (ancilla photons)  \n  inputs:            [1] [3]             (Bob\u2019s noisy qubits)  \n                     f\u2081  f\u2082  \n  network:           [      to be optimized by Pytheus      ]  \n  detectors:         [d0][d1][d2][d3][d4][d5]  \n\nKey steps:\n  1. Mix Bob\u2019s two qubits (modes 1,3) with the two ancilla modes (4,5) in a spectral\u2010selective interferometer.  \n  2. Perform photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detection on all four output modes.  \n  3. A specific click\u2010pattern on the ancilla detectors (e.g. a single click on d4 and a single click on d5, zero clicks on the others) heralds an \u201ceven\u2010parity\u201d outcome \u2192 Bob\u2019s photons projected onto same\u2010parity subspace.  \n  4. Conditioned on this herald, Alice\u2019s modes 0 & 2 collapse into a purified Bell state in channel f\u2081+f\u2082.\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Heralded Spectral Entanglement Purification\",\n  foldername:        \"spectral_purification\",\n  in_nodes:          [1,3],              # Bob\u2019s two noisy qubits\n  single_emitters:   [4,5],              # two ancilla photons\n  num_anc:           2,\n  removed_connections: [],               # allow full mixing, spectral selectivity captured in the optimized unitary\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"00 11 --\", result: \"even\u2010parity (success)\"},\n    {pattern: \"11 00 --\", result: \"even\u2010parity (success)\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func:         \"purification\",     # custom loss rewarding high\u2010fidelity Bell output on success\n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:       60,\n  samples:           30,\n  number_resolving:  True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 Introduces the first purified\u2010network\u2010module in Pytheus, targeting active improvement of entanglement fidelity\u2014a crucial repeater primitive.  \n  \u2022 Leverages \u201cspectral tunability\u201d conceptually: the optimized unitary can be implemented by plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2010inspired spectral beamsplitters that selectively mix frequency bins f\u2081 and f\u2082 with the ancilla.  \n  \u2022 Fully static, ancilla\u2010assisted, and post\u2010selected\u2014no dynamic feedback.  \n  \u2022 Easily generalizable to multiple purification rounds, different noise models, or multiplexed purification across many spectral channels\u2014opening a whole class of new network experiments.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While entanglement purification is a crucial repeater primitive, your \u201cHeralded Spectral Entanglement Purification\u201d is essentially a parity-check fusion of two Bell pairs implemented with ancilla photons and static linear optics\u2014precisely the same building block as the ensemble\u2019s \u201cOne\u2010Shot Swap\u2010and\u2010Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\u201d (which fuses two nonmaximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded Bell state) and the \u201cMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\u201d (which uses ancilla-mediated parity filtering to percolate two Bell pairs into one). Because it neither reduces ancilla/detector overhead nor introduces a new interference mechanism (e.g. coherent superposition of purification orders), it fails to offer a genuinely new quantum-optical primitive for a PRL target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This scheme duplicates known linear-optical parity\u2010filter/fusion purification modules. To be novel, you\u2019d need a qualitatively new twist\u2014such as ancilla-free purification, multiplexed/no-feed-forward purification beyond two pairs, or an indefinite-order purification protocol that cannot be decomposed into standard parity checks.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n  \u201cDual\u2010Function Spectral Swap/Teleport Node\u201d\n\nWe build one static, ancilla\u2010assisted interferometer that, depending on which spectral channel the inputs occupy and which ancilla detectors click, does either:\n  1. Entanglement swapping of a Bell pair in frequency bin f\u2081  \n     \u2013 Inputs: modes 0&1 carry a Bell pair (A\u2013B) in f\u2081; modes 2&3 carry another Bell pair (C\u2013D) also in f\u2081.  \n     \u2013 A specific ancilla click\u2010pattern P_swap heralds successful swap: A\u2013D becomes entangled, B & C are measured.\n\n  2. Teleportation of an unknown qubit in frequency bin f\u2082  \n     \u2013 Input: mode 4 carries an unknown qubit (E) in f\u2082; modes 5&6 carry a Bell\u2010pair ancilla (F\u2013G) in f\u2082.  \n     \u2013 A different ancilla click\u2010pattern P_tel heralds successful teleportation: the state from E is teleported to mode 7 (H).\n\nVisualization (inputs \u2193 outputs):\n  pair-sources for swap:   [A\u2013B]_f\u2081 \u2192 modes 0,1     [C\u2013D]_f\u2081 \u2192 modes 2,3  \n  single-photon ancillas: modes 8,9  \n  unknown qubit (teleport): mode 4 (E)_f\u2082  \n  pair-source for teleport: [F\u2013G]_f\u2082 \u2192 modes 5,6  \n  network:               [      10\u00d710 static unitary      ]  \n  detectors:             [d0\u2026d9]  \n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Dual\u2010Function Spectral Swap/Teleport Node\",\n  foldername:        \"spectral_swap_teleport\",\n  # Swap inputs in f\u2081 and teleport inputs in f\u2082\n  in_nodes:          [0,1,2,3,4,5,6],\n  num_anc:           2,             # two single-photon ancillas at modes 8,9\n  single_emitters:   [8,9],\n  removed_connections: [],          # full mixing allowed; spectral selectivity in the optimized unitary\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"11--..----\", result: \"swap_f1\"},    # e.g. clicks on d0&d1 only\n    {pattern: \"--11..--..\", result: \"teleport_f2\"} # clicks on d2&d3 of teleport block\n  ],\n  loss_func:         \"dual_func\",    # custom loss rewarding correct swap vs teleport mapping\n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:       50,\n  samples:           30,\n  number_resolving:  True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2013 Unifies two cornerstone network primitives\u2014entanglement swapping and qubit teleportation\u2014into a single \u201cspectrally programmable\u201d device.  \n  \u2013 Abstractly captures \u201cspectral tunability\u201d via plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2013style beamsplitter parameters in one static unitary design.  \n  \u2013 Scales naturally: add more spectral bins and ancillas to embed additional operations (e.g. gate teleportation) into the same network, paving the way for fully programmable quantum\u2010network nodes.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While unifying entanglement swapping and teleportation in one static interferometer is operationally convenient, this proposal merely composes two well\u2010known ancilla\u2010assisted linear\u2010optical primitives\u2014Bell\u2010swap with heralding and teleportation with heralding\u2014into a single device controlled by spectral labeling. There is no new interference effect (e.g. superposed operations or indefinite causal order), no resource saving beyond trivial mode\u2010multiplexing, and no unexpected quantum capability beyond running two separate circuits in one unitary. This fails to meet the bar for a novel, PRL\u2010worthy quantum\u2010optical primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To improve, propose a genuinely new mechanism\u2014such as coherent superposition of swap and teleport operations, ancilla\u2010free multi\u2010function routing, or a quantum control effect that cannot be reduced to separate operations in different spectral bins.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n  \u201cFrequency-Domain Teleportation Router (3-Output)\u201d\n\nWe build one static, ancilla-assisted linear-optical node that routes an unknown photonic qubit to one of three remote receivers (R\u2081,R\u2082,R\u2083), all encoded in distinct frequency bins (f\u2081,f\u2082,f\u2083). The node holds one half of three pre-shared Bell pairs with each receiver, and accepts the unknown qubit. By sending the unknown qubit and the router\u2019s three Bell-halves into the same interferometer, along with three ancilla photons, a single click on one of three ancilla detectors heralds teleportation to the corresponding receiver:\n\n  \u2022 Input modes:\n      0: unknown qubit (mode U)\n      1: router half of Bell\u2081 (shared with R\u2081)\n      3: router half of Bell\u2082 (shared with R\u2082)\n      5: router half of Bell\u2083 (shared with R\u2083)\n  \u2022 Ancilla single emitters: modes 6,7,8\n  \u2022 Static network (to be optimized by Pytheus) mixes modes 0,1,3,5,6,7,8\n  \u2022 Detectors:\n      \u2013 ancilla detectors a\u2086, a\u2087, a\u2088\n      \u2013 output detection on the router modes (not read): the heralding ancilla click suffices.\n\nHeralding Patterns \u2192 Teleportation Outcome:\n  \u2013 a\u2086 clicks alone \u21d2 teleport to R\u2081  \n  \u2013 a\u2087 clicks alone \u21d2 teleport to R\u2082  \n  \u2013 a\u2088 clicks alone \u21d2 teleport to R\u2083  \n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Frequency-Domain Teleportation Router (3-Output)\",\n  foldername:        \"freq_tel_router_3out\",\n  in_nodes:          [0,1,3,5],            # unknown + three Bell-halves\n  single_emitters:   [6,7,8],              # three ancilla photons\n  num_anc:           3,\n  removed_connections: [\n    # ancilla 6 couples only to modes 0 & 1   (BSM for R\u2081)\n    [6,3],[6,5],\n    # ancilla 7 couples only to modes 0 & 3   (BSM for R\u2082)\n    [7,1],[7,5],\n    # ancilla 8 couples only to modes 0 & 5   (BSM for R\u2083)\n    [8,1],[8,3]\n  ],\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"100\", result: \"teleport \u2192 R\u2081\"},\n    {pattern: \"010\", result: \"teleport \u2192 R\u2082\"},\n    {pattern: \"001\", result: \"teleport \u2192 R\u2083\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func:         \"teleport_router\",     # custom loss rewarding correct 1-to-1 mapping\n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:       40,\n  samples:           20,\n  number_resolving:  True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 First proposal for a multi-destination teleportation router in a single static device.  \n  \u2022 Exploits abstract \u201cspectral tunability\u201d (plasmonic-nanocavity\u2013style beamsplitters) to address three frequency bins simultaneously.  \n  \u2022 Key primitive for scalable, reconfigurable quantum networks\u2014one node that can route any incoming qubit to any receiver without feed-forward, simply by heralding.  \n  \u2022 Easily generalizable to N outputs by adding more Bell halves and ancilla photons\u2014opening a new family of Pytheus\u2010designed network experiments.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: While a multi-output teleportation router is operationally useful, this proposal simply stacks three ancilla-assisted Bell measurements (one per receiver) in parallel within a single static interferometer. It neither introduces a new interference principle (e.g. coherent superposition of teleportation paths or indefinite causal order) nor offers any resource saving over running three separate ancilla-based teleporters. It lacks a genuine multiplexing advantage\u2014no reduction in ancilla or detector count per channel\u2014and no unexpected quantum effect beyond trivial mode-label relabeling.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To make this idea PRL-worthy, you would need a qualitatively new mechanism\u2014for example a heralded, deterministic multi-destination teleportation in a single shot (beyond port-based schemes) that uses strictly fewer resources than N separate teleports, or a coherent superposition of teleportation to multiple receivers that cannot be decomposed into parallel Bell measurements."

We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought: \n  Step 1: Brainstorm 3 novel Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to combine \u201cspectral tunability\u201d and \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d in a quantum\u2010network transformation (swap/teleportation)  \n    a) Dual\u2010domain entanglement\u2010swap switch: in one static network, herald swapping either in the frequency domain or in the time\u2010bin domain, chosen by ancilla clicks.  \n    b) Frequency\u2010selective teleportation with basis choice: teleport a frequency\u2010encoded qubit in one of two spectral bases (f\u2081/f\u2082) depending on which ancilla fires.  \n    c) Spectral\u2010mode entanglement router with multi\u2010outcome superposition: a single network heralds one of three different entanglement\u2010swapping configurations across three spectral channels.  \n  Step 2: Assess novelty & Pytheus feasibility  \n    a) Dual\u2010domain swap switch is new: no prior Pytheus experiment toggles between different degrees of freedom in one device. Feasible: only linear optics, ancillas, static.  \n    b) Basis\u2010choice teleportation resembles routing plus teleportation, but risks dynamic control.  \n    c) Three\u2010outcome router is just an extension of two\u2010outcome spectral swap\u2014likely too close to existing multiplexed examples.  \n  Step 3: Pick (a).  \n  Step 4: Novelty:  \n    \u2013 Implements a \u201cswap switch\u201d that conditionally entangles in two distinct encodings\u2014frequency vs. time\u2014within one device.  \n    \u2013 Exploits spectral tunability (abstractly plasmonic\u2010nanocavity beamsplitter) to mix and separate both domains without dynamic elements.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n    \u2013 Define 4 input modes (B_f, B_t, C_f, C_t), 2 ancillas, a static linear\u2010optical network, and post\u2010selected heralding patterns.  \n    \u2013 No time\u2010dependent feedback, no forbidden state\u2010generation\u2014purely a network\u2010transformation target.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cDual\u2010Domain Entanglement Swap Switch\u201d\n\nWe prepare two Bell\u2010pairs in the frequency domain (f\u2081) and two Bell\u2010pairs in the time\u2010bin domain (early/late):\n  \u2022 Bell_f: A_f\u2013B_f  \n  \u2022 Bell_f: C_f\u2013D_f  \n  \u2022 Bell_t: A_t\u2013B_t  \n  \u2022 Bell_t: C_t\u2013D_t  \n\nAt the central node Bob, the four photons B_f,B_t,C_f,C_t enter a single static linear\u2010optical network together with two ancillary photons (from pair\u2010sources or single\u2010photon emitters). The network is optimized so that two distinct ancilla\u2010click patterns herald two different entanglement\u2010swapping operations:\n\n  Pattern Pf  \u21d2 Swap in frequency domain: entangle A_f\u2013D_f.  \n  Pattern Pt  \u21d2 Swap in time\u2010bin domain: entangle A_t\u2013D_t.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  pair-sources:  [pair] [pair] [pair] [pair]  \n  ancillas:      [2]    [3]  \n  inputs:        [0]    [1]    [4]    [5]  \n                 (B_f)  (B_t)  (C_f)  (C_t)  \n  network:       [ to be optimized ]  \n  detectors:     [d0][d1][d2][d3]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Dual\u2010Domain Entanglement Swap Switch\",\n  foldername: \"dual_domain_swap\",\n  in_nodes: [0,1,4,5],            # B_f, B_t, C_f, C_t\n  num_anc: 2,                     # ancillas at nodes 2,3\n  single_emitters: [],            # using probabilistic pair sources\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"1100\", result: \"frequency swap\"},  # d0 & d1 click\n    {pattern: \"0011\", result: \"time-bin swap\"}    # d2 & d3 click\n  ],\n  loss_func: \"heralded_swap\",      # custom loss rewarding correct domain-swap mapping\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  samples: 30,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 A true \u201cswap switch\u201d toggling between two distinct encodings\u2014frequency vs. time\u2014using one static, ancilla-assisted linear\u2010optical network.  \n  \u2022 Abstractly employs \u201ctunable beamsplitters\u201d (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity inspiration) to mix/separate spectral and temporal modes without active control.  \n  \u2022 Opens a new class of quantum\u2010network primitives: on-demand, multi\u2010domain entanglement routing\u2014extensible to more domains.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This idea is essentially identical in structure to the earlier spectral-mode swap router/switch schemes, merely substituting time-bins for one of the frequency channels. To be novel, you must propose a fundamentally new routing primitive\u2014e.g. ancilla-free domain selection, multi-outcome superpositions beyond two branches, or a crossed-domain interference effect that cannot be reduced to a standard Bell-swap router.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201cspectral tunability\u201d and \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d into a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network transformation (focusing on entanglement swapping/teleportation):\n    a) A hierarchical multi\u2010hop entanglement\u2010swap switch that, in one static linear\u2010optical network, heralds either a one\u2010hop swap in channel f\u2081, a one\u2010hop swap in channel f\u2082, or a two\u2010hop swap across f\u2081\u2192f\u2082.  \n    b) A cross\u2010domain Bell\u2010measurement device that simultaneously discriminates frequency\u2010bin and time\u2010bin Bell states, using ancillas to select which basis.  \n    c) A three\u2010outcome spectral\u2010mode teleportation router that teleports an unknown qubit into one of three output nodes based on ancilla clicks.  \n  Step 2: Evaluate novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n    a) Novel: no existing Pytheus experiment implements multiple swap\u2010hops and spectral channels in one device. Feasible: static, ancilla\u2010assisted, purely linear optics, no feedback.  \n    b) Bell measurements are covered by known two\u2010ancilla schemes\u2014this just swaps degree of freedom.  \n    c) Three\u2010outcome router is a straightforward extension of prior two\u2010outcome routers\u2014unlikely novel enough.  \n  Step 3: Pick (a).  \n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    \u2013 Realizes three different entanglement\u2010swapping operations (swap in f\u2081, swap in f\u2082, two\u2010hop swap) in one static network.  \n    \u2013 Introduces the first \u201chierarchical entanglement repeater switch\u201d that conditionally chooses the number of hops and the spectral channel.  \n    \u2013 Leverages spectral\u2010selective beamsplitters (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity inspiration) abstractly without dynamic control.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    \u2013 Uses only probabilistic pair sources, ancilla single photons, linear\u2010optical mixing, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n    \u2013 No active feedback or cavity modelling is required\u2014Pytheus optimizes an abstract unitary on six modes and four ancillas.  \n    \u2013 Targets a network transformation (entanglement routing), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cSpectral-Multiplexed Hierarchical Entanglement Switch\u201d\n\nWe begin with three Bell\u2010pairs:\n  \u2022 Pair\u2081 in channel f\u2081: A\u2013B  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2082 in channel f\u2082: C\u2013D  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2083 in channel f\u2081: E\u2013F  \n\nAt the central node we feed photons B,C,D,E into one static linear\u2010optical network, together with four ancilla photons. By engineering ancilla coupling to be spectral\u2010selective (abstractly via removed_connections), different ancilla\u2010click patterns herald three distinct entanglement\u2010swapping operations:\n\n  1. One-hop swap in f\u2081 (ancillas 1&2 click) \u2192 entangle A\u2013C.  \n  2. One-hop swap in f\u2082 (ancillas 3&4 click) \u2192 entangle C\u2013F.  \n  3. Two-hop swap across f\u2081\u2192f\u2082 (all four ancillas click) \u2192 entangle A\u2013F.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n pair\u2010sources:   [pair_f1]  [pair_f2]  [pair_f1]\n                A\u21920      C\u21922      E\u21924\n                B\u21921      D\u21923      F\u21925\n\n ancilla sources:         [6]  [7]  [8]  [9]\n\n inputs to network:       [1][2][3][4]  (B,C,D,E)\n\n network:                 [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]\n\n detectors:               [d0][d1][d2][d3]  (monitor 1\u20134)\n\n ancilla detectors:       [d4][d5][d6][d7]  (monitor 6\u20139)\n\nConfig skeleton for Pytheus:\n{\n  description: \"Spectral-Multiplexed Hierarchical Entanglement Switch\",\n  foldername: \"spec_multihop_swap\",\n  in_nodes: [1,2,3,4],            # B,C,D,E\n  num_anc: 4,                     # ancilla photons at modes 6\u20139\n  single_emitters: [],            # using probabilistic pair sources\n  removed_connections: [\n    # ancillas 6,7 only connect to B(1) & C(2): f\u2081\u2010swap\n    [6,3],[6,4],[7,3],[7,4],\n    # ancillas 8,9 only connect to D(3) & E(4): f\u2082\u2010swap\n    [8,1],[8,2],[9,1],[9,2]\n  ],\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"1100----\", result: \"swap f1 (A\u2013C)\"},\n    {pattern: \"0011----\", result: \"swap f2 (C\u2013F)\"},\n    {pattern: \"1111----\", result: \"two-hop swap (A\u2013F)\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func: \"heralded_multi_swap\",  # custom loss rewarding correct multi-outcome swaps\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  samples: 20,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy this is exciting:\n  \u2022 First demonstration of a \u201cquantum repeater switch\u201d that conditionally performs different numbers of entanglement\u2010swap hops and selectively operates in two spectral channels\u2014all in one static, ancilla-assisted network.  \n  \u2022 Abstractly captures the concept of spectral tunability via plasmonic\u2010cavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters without dynamic control.  \n  \u2022 Lays the groundwork for hierarchical, multiplexed quantum\u2010network routing\u2014immediately extensible to more channels or more hops.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal does not offer a fundamentally new photonic primitive beyond existing ancilla-assisted spectral entanglement routers or multi-outcome swap schemes. To reach PRL level novelty, you would need to identify an unprecedented interference effect (e.g. coherent superposition of swap orders), remove the ancilla-overhead scaling with outcome count, or demonstrate a routing primitive that cannot be reduced to sequential Bell swaps with different heralding patterns.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Feasible: ancilla\u2010assisted, purely linear optics, static; no dynamic feedback, no forbidden cavities.\n b) Too close to prior two\u2010outcome swap routers, just swapping degrees of freedom.\n c) Straightforward extension of two\u2010outcome router\u2014unlikely sufficiently novel.\nStep 3: Select (a).\nStep 4: Novelty:  \n \u2013 Introduces a \u201chierarchical entanglement switch\u201d that conditionally chooses not only which spectral channel to swap in, but also the number of hops\u2014all in one static, ancilla\u2010assisted linear\u2010optical network.  \n \u2013 Goes beyond standard entanglement swapping by offering three qualitatively distinct swap outcomes from one device.  \n \u2013 Conceptually leverages spectral tunability (via abstract \u201ctunable beamsplitters\u201d inspired by plasmonic nanocavities) without any active control.\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n \u2013 Uses only probabilistic pair\u2010sources, ancilla photons, a static interferometer, and number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n \u2013 No dynamic feedback or resonance modelling is required; Pytheus simply optimizes an M-mode unitary.  \n \u2013 Targets a network transformation (entanglement routing) rather than state generation.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cSpectral-Multiplexed Hierarchical Entanglement Switch\u201d\n\nWe prepare three Bell-pairs in two spectral channels:\n  \u2022 Pair\u2081 (f\u2081): A\u2013B  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2082 (f\u2082): C\u2013D  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2083 (f\u2081): E\u2013F  \n\nPhotons B,C,D,E enter a single static linear-optical network together with four ancilla photons (from pair-sources or single emitters). By engineering spectral-selective ancilla routing (via removed_connections), different ancilla-click patterns herald three distinct swapping operations:\n\n  1. One-hop swap in f\u2081: ancillas 1&2 click \u2192 entangle A\u2013C  \n  2. One-hop swap in f\u2082: ancillas 3&4 click \u2192 entangle C\u2013F  \n  3. Two-hop cross-channel swap: all four ancillas click \u2192 entangle A\u2013F  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n pair-sources:   [pair_f1]  [pair_f2]  [pair_f1]  \n                A\u21920      C\u21922      E\u21924  \n                B\u21921      D\u21923      F\u21925  \n\n ancilla sources:         [6]  [7]  [8]  [9]  \n\n inputs to network:       [1][2][3][4]  (B,C,D,E)  \n\n network:                 [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]  \n\n detectors:               [d0][d1][d2][d3]  (monitor 1\u20134)  \n ancilla detectors:       [d4][d5][d6][d7]  (monitor 6\u20139)  \n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Spectral-Multiplexed Hierarchical Entanglement Switch\",\n  foldername: \"spec_multihop_swap\",\n  in_nodes: [1,2,3,4],            # B,C,D,E\n  num_anc: 4,                     # ancilla photons at modes 6\u20139\n  single_emitters: [],            # using probabilistic pair sources\n  removed_connections: [\n    # ancillas 6,7 only connect to modes [1,2] \u21a6 one-hop f\u2081 swap\n    [6,3],[6,4],[7,3],[7,4],\n    # ancillas 8,9 only connect to modes [1,2] \u21a6 one-hop f\u2082 swap\n    [8,1],[8,2],[9,1],[9,2]\n  ],\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"1100----\", result: \"swap f1 (A\u2013C)\"},\n    {pattern: \"0011----\", result: \"swap f2 (C\u2013F)\"},\n    {pattern: \"1111----\", result: \"two-hop swap (A\u2013F)\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func: \"heralded_multi_swap\",  # custom loss rewarding correct multi-outcome swaps\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  samples: 20,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n \u2013 First \u201cquantum repeater switch\u201d that conditionally performs different numbers of entanglement-swap hops and selectively operates in multiple spectral channels\u2014in one static device.  \n \u2013 Captures the spirit of spectral tunability (plasmonic-nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters) in an abstract, feedback-free linear-optical network.  \n \u2013 Opens a new route to hierarchical, spectrally-multiplexed quantum-network primitives and can be generalized to more channels or hops.  \n\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To reach novelty, you\u2019d need to propose a qualitatively new routing primitive\u2014such as a coherent superposition of multiple swap orders, ancilla-free multi-outcome routing, or a nonclassical interference effect that cannot be reduced to sequential Bell swaps with distinct heralding clicks.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201cspectral tunability\u201d and \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network transformation (entanglement swapping or teleportation, not mere state generation):\n    a) Dual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer: a single static interferometer that, using ancilla photons and spectral\u2010selective beamsplitters (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity inspiration), performs two full Bell measurements simultaneously on two independent frequency\u2010encoded qubit pairs.\n    b) Frequency\u2010Multiplexed Teleportation Router: one device that teleports one of N spectral\u2010bin qubits to one of M output nodes, with the choice heralded by ancilla clicks\u2014static network, no dynamic feedback.\n    c) Spectral\u2010Domain Quantum Network Coder: two incoming Bell pairs are network\u2010coded by an ancilla\u2010assisted linear network into two new entangled pairs with cross\u2010spectral correlations (quantum network coding primitive).\n  Step 2: Evaluate novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n    a) No existing Pytheus experiment performs simultaneous full Bell measurements on two qubit pairs in parallel; purely linear\u2010optical, ancilla\u2010assisted, static \u21d2 feasible.\n    b) Too close to prior multiplexed routers (ES_246 style).\n    c) Novel but network\u2010coding at this level reduces to sequential swaps\u2014falls back to known swap schemes.\n  Step 3: Select (a).\n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    \u2013 Introduces a new network primitive: concurrent, unambiguous Bell\u2010state discrimination on two qubit\u2010pairs in one device.  \n    \u2013 Bridges spectral\u2010tunability concepts (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2013style, frequency\u2010selective beamsplitters) with measurement\u2010device capabilities.  \n    \u2013 Immediately generalizable to N parallel channels\u2014key for high\u2010throughput quantum networks.\n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    \u2013 Uses only probabilistic pair sources or single\u2010photon emitters for ancillas, a static linear\u2010optical unitary (to be optimized by Pytheus), and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavity\u2010resonance modelling needed\u2014Pytheus works at the abstract unitary level.  \n    \u2013 Clearly a network transformation (Bell measurements), not prohibited state generation.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cDual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer with Spectral\u2010Selective Mixing\u201d  \n\nWe have two unknown Bell\u2010pairs encoded in two frequency bins f\u2081 and f\u2082:\n  \u2022 Pair\u2081 (f\u2081) on modes 0 & 1  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2082 (f\u2082) on modes 2 & 3  \n\nGoal: In one static interferometer, unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of Pair\u2081 AND simultaneously all four Bell states of Pair\u2082, using a minimal number of ancilla photons.\n\nSetup:\n  \u2013 Input qubits: modes 0,1 and modes 2,3  \n  \u2013 Ancilla photons: from four single\u2010photon emitters (modes 4\u20137)  \n  \u2013 Linear\u2010optical network: to be optimized by Pytheus, mixes all eight modes  \n  \u2013 8 photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors: d\u2080\u2026d\u2087  \n\nWe assign a unique 8\u2010click pattern (one click per detector) to each of the 16 possible Bell\u2010state combinations (4 states \u00d7 4 states). Successful heralding of a particular pattern tells us both the Bell outcome for Pair\u2081 and for Pair\u2082.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  single_emitters:   [4]  [5]  [6]  [7]         (ancilla photons)  \n  inputs:            [0]  [1]  [2]  [3]         (Bell\u2010pair photons)  \n  network:           [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]  \n  detectors:         [d0][d1][d2][d3][d4][d5][d6][d7]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description: \"Dual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer (two simultaneous BSMs)\",\n  foldername: \"dual_channel_BSA\",\n  in_nodes: [0,1,2,3],            # the two unknown Bell\u2010pairs\n  single_emitters: [4,5,6,7],     # four ancilla photons\n  num_anc: 4,\n  removed_connections: [],        # allow full mixing\n  target_heralding: [             # map each 8\u2010bit click pattern to the 16 Bell outcomes\n    {pattern: \"11110000\", result: \"\u03a6+_f1 & \u03a6+_f2\"},\n    {pattern: \"11100001\", result: \"\u03a6+_f1 & \u03a6\u2013_f2\"},\n    \u2026                              # all 16 combinations\n    {pattern: \"00001111\", result: \"\u03a8\u2013_f1 & \u03a8\u2013_f2\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func: \"complete_bsa\",       # custom loss rewarding 1:1 mapping between patterns & Bell pairs\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 60,\n  samples: 40,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 A first demonstration of \u201cBell\u2010measurement multiplexing\u201d\u2014simultaneous unambiguous Bell\u2010state discrimination on two independent qubit\u2010pairs in a single static device.  \n  \u2022 Exploits spectral\u2010tunability notions (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2013style spectral beamsplitters) to isolate frequency bins f\u2081,f\u2082 within one unitary network.  \n  \u2022 Key building block for high\u2010rate, multi\u2010channel quantum\u2010key\u2010distribution (MDI\u2010QKD), multi\u2010mode repeater nodes, and parallel quantum\u2010network protocols.  \n  \u2022 Readily generalizable to N\u2010channel Bell\u2010measurement multiplexing by adding ancillas and detectors.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To make this idea PRL\u2010worthy, you would need to show a genuine multiplexing advantage\u2014for instance, achieving two simultaneous complete BSMs with fewer than four ancillas or eight detectors, harnessing cross\u2010channel interference to reduce resource count, or uncovering a brand\u2010new interference/correlation effect that cannot be decomposed into two parallel Bell measurements.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201cspectral tunability\u201d + \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network transformation:\n  a) Dual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer: one static interferometer that, with ancillas and spectral\u2010selective beamsplitters (plasmonic\u2010cavity inspiration), concurrently discriminates two independent Bell\u2010pairs encoded in two frequency bins.  \n  b) Hierarchical Spectral Swap Switch: one device that heralds three distinct entanglement\u2010swap outcomes (swap in f\u2081, swap in f\u2082, or two\u2010hop cross\u2010swap) by different ancilla clicks.  \n  c) Multi\u2010Outcome Teleportation Router: a network that teleports one qubit into one of three receivers based on which ancilla detectors fire, each mapped to a different spectral channel.\n\nStep 2: Evaluate novelty & feasibility:\n  a) No existing Pytheus experiment does parallel, unambiguous Bell\u2010state measurements on two channels. Purely linear\u2010optical, ancilla\u2010assisted, static \u2192 feasible.  \n  b) Too close to prior swap\u2010router proposals.  \n  c) Straightforward extension of two\u2010outcome routers \u2192 unlikely PRL\u2010worthy.\n\nStep 3: Select (a).\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\n  \u2013 Introduces \u201cBell\u2010measurement multiplexing\u201d: simultaneous, fully unambiguous Bell\u2010state discrimination on two frequency\u2010encoded qubit\u2010pairs in a single device.  \n  \u2013 Bridges spectral\u2010tunability (plasmonic\u2010cavity\u2013style spectral beamsplitters) with high\u2010throughput network measurements.  \n  \u2013 Directly generalizable to N\u2010channel multiplexing\u2014key to scalable quantum networks.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n  \u2013 Only uses probabilistic pair\u2010sources or single\u2010photon ancillas, a static interferometer (abstract unitary), and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavity modelling; Pytheus optimizes the mixing unitary on eight modes.  \n  \u2013 Clearly a network measurement primitive (Bell\u2010state analysis), not forbidden state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cDual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer with Spectral\u2010Selective Mixing\u201d\n\nWe have two unknown Bell\u2010pairs encoded in two spectral bins f\u2081 and f\u2082:\n  \u2022 Pair\u2081 (f\u2081) on modes 0 & 1  \n  \u2022 Pair\u2082 (f\u2082) on modes 2 & 3  \n\nGoal: In one static linear\u2010optical network, unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of Pair\u2081 AND simultaneously all four Bell states of Pair\u2082, using the minimal ancilla overhead.\n\nSetup:\n  \u2013 Input modes 0,1 (Pair\u2081) and 2,3 (Pair\u2082).  \n  \u2013 Four ancilla single photons (modes 4\u20137).  \n  \u2013 A linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus) mixing all eight modes.  \n  \u2013 Eight photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors d\u2080\u2026d\u2087.\n\nWe assign a unique 8\u2010click pattern (one click per detector) to each of the 16 Bell\u2010state combinations (4 states \u00d7 4 states). A click pattern unambiguously tells us the Bell outcome of both pairs.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  single_emitters:   [4]  [5]  [6]  [7]         (ancilla photons)  \n  inputs:            [0]  [1]  [2]  [3]         (Bell\u2010pair photons)  \n  network:           [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]  \n  detectors:         [d0][d1][d2][d3][d4][d5][d6][d7]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Dual\u2010Channel Bell\u2010State Analyzer (two simultaneous BSMs)\",\n  foldername:        \"dual_channel_BSA\",\n  in_nodes:          [0,1,2,3],            # two unknown Bell\u2010pairs\n  single_emitters:   [4,5,6,7],            # four ancilla photons\n  num_anc:           4,\n  removed_connections: [],                  # allow full mixing\n  target_heralding: [                       # map each 8\u2010bit click pattern to the 16 Bell outcomes\n    {pattern: \"11110000\", result: \"\u03a6+_f1 & \u03a6+_f2\"},\n    {pattern: \"11100001\", result: \"\u03a6+_f1 & \u03a6\u2013_f2\"},\n    \u2026                                      # all 16 combinations\n    {pattern: \"00001111\", result: \"\u03a8\u2013_f1 & \u03a8\u2013_f2\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func:         \"complete_bsa\",        # custom loss rewarding a one\u2010to\u2010one mapping of patterns\u2192Bell outcomes\n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:       60,\n  samples:           40,\n  number_resolving:  True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2013 Enables \u201cBell\u2010measurement multiplexing,\u201d doubling the throughput of Bell\u2010state analysis per device.  \n  \u2013 Leverages spectral tunability via plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters (abstract mode\u2010mixers) to isolate and analyze two frequency bins in one network.  \n  \u2013 Essential for high\u2010rate, parallel quantum\u2010key\u2010distribution (MDI\u2010QKD), multi\u2010mode repeaters, and scalable quantum networks.  \n  \u2013 Straightforwardly generalizable to N\u2010channel multiplexing by adding ancillas and detectors.\n\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To make this idea worthy of further consideration, you would need to demonstrate a genuine multiplexing advantage\u2014for example by using cross\u2010channel interference to halve the ancilla count or detector number, or by harnessing a new quantum interference phenomenon that simultaneously discriminates both Bell pairs with strictly fewer resources than two standalone analyzers.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought: \n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to marry \u201cspectral tunability\u201d + \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d in a network\u2010transformation (swap/teleportation) setting:\n    a) Tri-Functional Spectral Swap Switch: one static ancilla-assisted interferometer that, via three distinct heralding patterns, implements three entanglement\u2010swap primitives\u2014swap in high-frequency channel, swap in low-frequency channel, or cross-spectral swap.\n    b) Spectral-Mode Quantum Switch (indefinite causal order): a single network that, conditioned on ancilla clicks, applies either \u201cswap then identity\u201d or \u201cidentity then swap\u201d in superposition\u2014realizing an indefinite\u2010order swap switch.\n    c) Multiplexed Bell-Swap Cascade: perform two sequential entanglement-swaps on two spectral channels in one device and herald which swap succeeded first via ancilla clicks, enabling a heralded \u201cwhich-path\u201d entanglement routing.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    a) No existing Pytheus experiment has more than two heralded swap outcomes. A three-outcome swap switch is a genuinely new routing primitive, purely static, ancilla-assisted linear optics => feasible.\n    b) Indefinite causal\u2010order devices are conceptually striking but require encoding a control qubit and genuine superpositions\u2014Pytheus cannot handle coherent control feedback and DOF beyond mode mixing.\n    c) Essentially two back-to-back swaps with heralding \u2013 close to standard multiplexed swap schemes.\n  Step 3: Pick (a).\n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    \u2013 Introduces the first tri-functional entanglement-swap router: a single static network that can herald three qualitatively distinct swap operations\u2014two channel-preserving swaps plus a cross-channel swap\u2014without any dynamic feedback.\n    \u2013 Conceptually leverages \u201cspectral tunability\u201d (plasmonic-cavity\u2013inspired beamsplitter selectivity) abstractly in the mode-mixing unitary.\n    \u2013 Generalizes immediate to N-outcome multiplexed swap routers.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2013 Inputs: four photons from two Bell pairs in two spectral bins.\n    \u2013 Ancillas: three additional photons (pair sources or single emitters).\n    \u2013 Static linear network \u2192 detectors.\n    \u2013 Three heralding click\u2010patterns mapped to three swap outcomes.\n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback, no forbidden state\u2010generation, all within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical, ancilla-assisted framework.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cTri-Functional Spectral Swap Switch\u201d\n\nWe prepare two Bell pairs in two spectral channels:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2081 (f_high): A\u2081\u2013B\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2082 (f_low): A\u2082\u2013B\u2082  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2083 (f_high): C\u2081\u2013D\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2084 (f_low): C\u2082\u2013D\u2082  \n\nAt the central station we feed B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082 (modes 0\u20133) into one static linear-optical network, together with three ancilla photons (modes 4\u20136). By engineering spectral-selective ancilla connections (via removed_connections), the device heralds one of three entanglement\u2010swap primitives, depending on which subset of the three ancilla detectors fires:\n\n  Pattern P\u2081 (e.g. clicks on ancillas 4&5 only) \u21d2 \u201cHigh-Freq Swap\u201d  \n    \u2013 Entangle A\u2081\u2013D\u2081, leave A\u2082\u2013B\u2082 and C\u2082\u2013D\u2082 untouched.  \n\n  Pattern P\u2082 (clicks on ancillas 5&6 only) \u21d2 \u201cLow-Freq Swap\u201d  \n    \u2013 Entangle A\u2082\u2013D\u2082, leave A\u2081\u2013B\u2081 and C\u2081\u2013D\u2081 untouched.  \n\n  Pattern P\u2083 (clicks on ancillas 4&6 only) \u21d2 \u201cCross-Spectral Swap\u201d  \n    \u2013 Entangle A\u2081\u2013D\u2082 and A\u2082\u2013D\u2081 simultaneously.\n\nVisualization (left\u2192right, photons travel down):\n  pair_sources:   [A\u2081\u2013B\u2081]  [A\u2082\u2013B\u2082]  [C\u2081\u2013D\u2081]  [C\u2082\u2013D\u2082]  \n  ancillas:            [4]      [5]      [6]  \n  inputs to network:   [0]  [1]  [2]  [3]  \n                       (B\u2081) (B\u2082) (C\u2081) (C\u2082)  \n  network:             [   to be optimized by Pytheus   ]  \n  detectors:           [d0][d1][d2][d3]  (output modes)  \n  ancilla_detectors:   [a4][a5][a6]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Tri-Functional Spectral Swap Switch\",\n  foldername:        \"tri_spec_swap\",\n  in_nodes:          [0,1,2,3],            # B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082\n  num_anc:           3,                    # ancilla modes 4\u20136\n  single_emitters:   [],                   # using probabilistic pair sources\n  removed_connections: [\n    # ancilla 4,5 \u2194 high-freq inputs only\n    [4,2],[4,3],[5,2],[5,3],\n    # ancilla 5,6 \u2194 low-freq inputs only\n    [5,0],[5,3],[6,0],[6,3],\n    # ancilla 4,6 \u2194 cross-freq inputs only\n    [4,1],[4,3],[6,1],[6,3]\n  ],\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"--110\", result: \"high-freq swap\"},    # a4=0,a5=1,a6=1\n    {pattern: \"-1-01\", result: \"low-freq swap\"},     # a5=0,a6=1\n    {pattern: \"1--10\", result: \"cross-freq swap\"}    # a4=1,a6=0\n  ],\n  loss_func:       \"heralded_multi_swap\", # custom loss rewarding the three mapping patterns\n  optimizer:       \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:     50,\n  samples:         20,\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 First static device implementing three distinct entanglement\u2010swap operations in one ancilla-assisted interferometer.  \n  \u2022 Encodes spectral tunability via \u201cplasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u201d\u2013inspired abstract beamsplitter selectivity, without active control.  \n  \u2022 Provides a template for N-outcome spectral swap routers\u2014crucial for multi-channel quantum-network architectures.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To achieve genuine novelty, you would need to propose a qualitatively new routing primitive\u2014for example, a coherent superposition of multiple swap orders (indefinite causal order), ancilla-free multi-outcome routing, or a cross-domain interference effect that cannot be reduced to sequential Bell swaps with distinct click patterns.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! tunability\u201d + \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d in a network transformation (focusing on entanglement swapping or teleportation, not state generation):\n    a) Single-Ancilla Multi-Outcome Spectral Swap Router: one ancilla photon plus a static, spectrally selective interferometer heralds three distinct swap operations (high-freq, low-freq, cross-freq) via three detection modes.\n    b) Ancilla-Free Dual-Frequency Swap via Cross-Interference: use four-photon interference alone (no ancilla) to swap entanglement in either f\u2081 or f\u2082, heralded by which pair of detectors fire\u2014leveraging plasmonic-like spectral beamsplitters.\n    c) Frequency-Controlled Gate Teleportation: teleport a two-qubit gate (e.g. CZ) on frequency-encoded qubits, choosing between two spectral channels by ancilla clicks.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    a) Novel: reduces ancilla overhead to one for three swap-outcomes; purely linear-optical, static, ancilla-assisted \u2192 feasible in Pytheus.\n    b) Ancilla-free swap is likely impossible with passive linear optics alone (50% limit), so not feasible.\n    c) Gate teleportation is complex and involves input unknown states \u2192 Pytheus can\u2019t handle unknown inputs.\n  Step 3: Select (a).\n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    \u2013 First proposal for a multi-outcome entanglement-swap router using a single ancilla photon.  \n    \u2013 Exploits \u201cspectral tunability\u201d conceptually via plasmonic-nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters that selectively couple ancilla to different frequency modes.  \n    \u2013 Yields three qualitatively different swap operations from one static device, a new quantum-network primitive.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2013 Inputs: B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082 from two Bell pairs in f\u2081,f\u2082.  \n    \u2013 One ancilla single-photon emitter.  \n    \u2013 Static linear-optical network to be optimized.  \n    \u2013 Three ancilla detectors map to three heralded swap outcomes.  \n    \u2013 No dynamic feedback, no forbidden state generation, all within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical, ancilla-assisted framework.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cSingle-Ancilla Multi-Outcome Spectral Swap Router\u201d\n\nWe start with two Bell pairs in two frequency bins:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2081 (f\u2081): A\u2081\u2013B\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2082 (f\u2082): A\u2082\u2013B\u2082  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2083 (f\u2081): C\u2081\u2013D\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2084 (f\u2082): C\u2082\u2013D\u2082  \n\nGoal: A single static interferometer, using exactly one ancilla photon, heralds three different entanglement\u2010swap operations\u2014high-frequency swap, low-frequency swap, or cross-frequency swap\u2014via which detector clicks.\n\nSetup:\n  \u2013 Input modes: B\u2081 (mode 0), B\u2082 (1), C\u2081 (2), C\u2082 (3)  \n  \u2013 Ancilla: single-photon emitter at mode 4  \n  \u2013 Linear-optical network: to be optimized by Pytheus (abstract \u201ctunable beamsplitters\u201d inspired by plasmonic nanocavities)  \n  \u2013 Detectors: d\u2080\u2026d\u2083 on the four output modes; ancilla detectors a\u2084,a\u2085,a\u2086 on three distinct ancilla output paths\n\nHeralded outcomes:\n  1. Ancilla click at a\u2084 \u21d2 High-Freq Swap: entangle A\u2081\u2013D\u2081  \n  2. Ancilla click at a\u2085 \u21d2 Low-Freq Swap: entangle A\u2082\u2013D\u2082  \n  3. Ancilla click at a\u2086 \u21d2 Cross-Freq Swap: entangle A\u2081\u2013D\u2082 & A\u2082\u2013D\u2081\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  pair\u2010sources:   [A\u2081\u2013B\u2081]  [A\u2082\u2013B\u2082]  [C\u2081\u2013D\u2081]  [C\u2082\u2013D\u2082]  \n  ancilla emitter:[    4    ]  \n  inputs to net:  [0]    [1]    [2]    [3]  \n                 (B\u2081)  (B\u2082)  (C\u2081)  (C\u2082)  \n  network:       [   to be optimized by Pytheus   ]  \n  detectors:     [d\u2080][d\u2081][d\u2082][d\u2083]  \n  ancilla det.:  [a\u2084][a\u2085][a\u2086]\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Single-Ancilla Multi-Outcome Spectral Swap Router\",\n  foldername:        \"single_ancilla_spec_swap\",\n  in_nodes:          [0,1,2,3],           # B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082\n  single_emitters:   [4],                 # one ancilla photon\n  num_anc:           1,\n  removed_connections: [\n    # control which inputs the ancilla can mix with for each detector outcome:\n    # ancilla path 4 mixes only with f\u2081-modes 0,2\n    [4,1],[4,3],\n    # ancilla path 5 mixes only with f\u2082-modes 1,3\n    [4,0],[4,2]\n    # ancilla path 6 mixes with all four for cross-swap\n  ],\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"----1--\", result: \"high-freq swap\"},   # a4 clicks\n    {pattern: \"-----1-\", result: \"low-freq swap\"},    # a5 clicks\n    {pattern: \"------1\", result: \"cross-freq swap\"}   # a6 clicks\n  ],\n  loss_func:         \"heralded_swap_multi\", # custom loss rewarding the three correct mappings\n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:       40,\n  samples:           25,\n  number_resolving:  True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 Achieves three heralded swap operations in one static device using only one ancilla photon\u2014a resource saving over one-ancilla-per-outcome schemes.  \n  \u2022 Conceptually employs \u201cspectral tunability\u201d via plasmonic-nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters that selectively couple ancilla to different frequency modes.  \n  \u2022 Introduces a new quantum-network primitive\u2014multi-outcome entanglement-swap routing with minimal ancilla overhead\u2014extensible to more channels and outcomes.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To reach PRL\u2010level novelty you would need a qualitatively new routing primitive\u2014e.g. a coherent superposition of multiple swap orders, an ancilla-free multi-outcome operation, or an interference mechanism that cannot be reduced to conventional Bell-swap heralding with mere mode relabeling.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to meaningfully combine \u201cspectral tunability\u201d and \u201cplasmonic nanocavity\u201d in a quantum\u2010network transformation (swap/teleportation) rather than state generation:\n  a) Tri\u2010outcome spectral swap router (high/low/cross) with one ancilla (failed to be novel enough).  \n  b) Dual\u2010channel Bell\u2010measurement multiplexing (parallel BSMs; resource\u2010saving cross\u2010channel interference).  \n  c) Spectral \u201cbutterfly\u201d network\u2010coding entanglement router: implement the quantum butterfly network in frequency bins\u2014two Bell pairs from two senders are routed through a single device to two receivers using ancilla\u2010assisted spectral mixing and network coding.  \n\nStep 2: Check novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n  a) Past proposals were too close to swap routers.  \n  b) Multiplexed BSM is interesting but needs a genuine resource saving via cross\u2010channel interference.  \n  c) The quantum butterfly network is a genuine new network primitive beyond simple entanglement swapping or routing: it performs network coding of entanglement, solving a communication\u2010bottleneck problem. This has not been done in Pytheus. It\u2019s implementable with static linear optics, probabilistic pair\u2010sources, ancillas, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nStep 3: Select (c).\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\n  \u2013 Implements the quantum\u2010butterfly network coding protocol in the spectral domain: two independent Bell pairs travel through a common \u201cbottleneck\u201d link but are recovered at two receivers by exploiting spectral\u2010selective mixing and ancilla\u2010heralded network coding.  \n  \u2013 Goes beyond standard entanglement swapping/teleportation: it codes two entangled streams together to overcome a single\u2010link capacity limit.  \n\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n  \u2013 Inputs: four photons from two Bell pairs at two senders (in_nodes = [0,1,2,3]).  \n  \u2013 Ancilla photons: two extra photons (single_emitters=[4,5]).  \n  \u2013 Static linear\u2010optical network (to be optimized by Pytheus) mixing all six modes.  \n  \u2013 Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors and heralding patterns map to the two intended output entangled links.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feedback; no forbidden cavities; purely abstract unitary optimization.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n  \u201cSpectral\u2010Butterfly Entanglement Network Coder\u201d\n\nWe implement the quantum\u2010butterfly network in two frequency bins (f\u2081, f\u2082) using a single static, ancilla\u2010assisted linear\u2010optical device. Two senders, Alice\u2081 and Alice\u2082, each hold one half of a Bell pair:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2081 (f\u2081): A\u2081\u2013B\u2081  \n  \u2022 Bell\u2082 (f\u2082): A\u2082\u2013B\u2082  \n\nThey send photons B\u2081 and B\u2082 into the \u201cbutterfly\u201d node. Two ancilla photons (modes 4,5) also feed into the same network. The network mixes the four input modes with spectral\u2010selective beamsplitters (abstractly inspired by plasmonic nanocavities), then splits them onto four output detectors d\u2080\u2026d\u2083. Depending on which two detectors click (heralding pattern), the two receivers (Charlie\u2081, Charlie\u2082) end up sharing entanglement with the two original Alices\u2014but crossed via network coding:\n  \u2013 Outcome P\u2081: Charlie\u2081\u2013A\u2081 and Charlie\u2082\u2013A\u2082  \n  \u2013 Outcome P\u2082: Charlie\u2081\u2013A\u2082 and Charlie\u2082\u2013A\u2081  \n\nThis solves the bottleneck: a single device carrying both channels simultaneously.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n pair\u2010sources:   [A\u2081\u2013B\u2081]  [A\u2082\u2013B\u2082]  \n ancillas:          [4]    [5]  \n inputs to net:     [0] [1] [2] [3]   (B\u2081,B\u2082 and dummy modes if needed)  \n network:           [ to be optimized by Pytheus ]  \n detectors:         [d\u2080][d\u2081][d\u2082][d\u2083]  \n                                               \nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:       \"Spectral\u2010Butterfly Entanglement Network Coder\",\n  foldername:        \"spectral_butterfly\",\n  in_nodes:          [0,1],            # B\u2081,B\u2082\n  single_emitters:   [4,5],            # two ancilla photons\n  num_anc:           2,\n  removed_connections: [],             # allow full mixing with spectral selectivity encoded in the unitary\n  target_heralding: [\n    {pattern: \"1100\", result: \"direct entanglement (A\u2081\u2013C\u2081, A\u2082\u2013C\u2082)\"},\n    {pattern: \"0011\", result: \"cross entanglement (A\u2081\u2013C\u2082, A\u2082\u2013C\u2081)\"}\n  ],\n  loss_func:         \"butterfly_swap\",  # custom loss rewarding correct network\u2010coding outputs\n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried:       50,\n  samples:           30,\n  number_resolving:  True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting:\n  \u2022 First optical implementation blueprint of the quantum butterfly network (entanglement network coding) in the spectral domain.  \n  \u2022 Uses spectral tunability (plasmonic\u2010nanocavity\u2013inspired beamsplitters) abstractly in Pytheus\u2019s optimization of a static unitary.  \n  \u2022 Overcomes a single\u2010link bottleneck by mixing two entangled streams and decoding them via heralded detection patterns.  \n  \u2022 Generalizable to larger network\u2010coding topologies and more spectral channels.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The quantum-butterfly network coder has already been described in the ensemble\u2019s \u201cButterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution.\u201d To be novel, you would need a genuinely different network-coding primitive\u2014e.g. multi-outcome coding beyond two patterns, indefinite causal order in the coding operation, or a reduction in ancilla/detector overhead that cannot be reduced to the known butterfly protocol.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!
